Black Butler was an anime that effective mixed elements of black comedy, mystery and the supernatural exploring Ciel's involvement with various paranormal mysteries while seeking revenge with the help of his butler, Sebastian. The major bone of the series is focused around the bond between Sebastian and Ciel. The chemistry between the two is an interesting one considering their deal and Sebastian's not-so-normal origins. Both tend to snark on one another frequently in regards to their actions and thoughts with Ciel reprimanding Sebastian for some of his thoughtless actions and Sebastian going after Ciel for showing signs of remorse towards any victim caught in theway of his plans of revenge. Both however do show concern of one another thanks to the conditions of their deal.


In terms of the show's comedy, Black Butler gets its kicks off poking fun of the surprisingly funny moments coming from the show's various dark figures. From seeing an undertaker want jokes as payment for information related to a murder to an anachronism related to a Grim Reaper's weapon to some shocking information regarding the bungling servants of the Phantomhive manor, the show does well for the most part at delivering its laughs when you would least expect it.


The series is mostly spread out into a number of arcs where Ciel is sent to investigate random mysteries with aid from Sebastian where the circumstances to each case are not as they seem on the surface. The mysteries mix around both their serious and funny moments in regards to the supernatural origins regarding a perpetrator or are connected to Ciel's tragic past as he seeks his revenge. The show dabbles into quite a bit of dark territory with its mysteries showing the most corrupt sides of the human psyche with a number of characters who are aware or unaware of how flawed they truly are. This also rings true with Ciel's character as despite how corrupt he believes himself to have become because of his deal with Sebastian that he still retains some signs of morality, even while in denial of it.


In terms of visuals, Black Butler sports scenery which is vast and sporting a great amount of detail as there are a variety of settings to take in from city landscapes to countrysides to being on ships. The subdued color tones used with the settings and character designs do well at complementing the dark and gritty mood that the series gives off. However for a series that puts focus on its action, Black Butler's animation is noticeably subpar at points with shortcuts being apparent in action scenes with the only moments of highlight with animation coming from the movement coming from ships and horse carriages rendered in CG animation.


Overall, I got enough enjoyment out of seeing Black Butler thanks to its surprisingly funny black comedy, chemistry between Ciel and Sebastian and the developments surrounding Ciel's search for those responsible for his family's murder. If you are looking to get your laughs off of more macabre moments with solid plot development tossed into the mix, then Black Butler offers up a worthwhile choice for you to look into.

Holy chiz.
What.... What is this madness?
Where do I begin?
Not much catches my interest. I'm pretty picky when it comes to shows and manga. I like things that are dark and funny, philosophical and tragic, deep and moving, unique and quirky. I hadn't believed I'd really like this. 
I was wrong.
Black Butler is complex as hell. It's like, you start out with this simple anime, this show made purely for entertainment, and as you go on, without even realizing it, it becomes darker and more complicated. You see into the tragic pasts, the characters' emotional pains, the inevitable future, and your left going, "HOLY SHIT, WHATJUST HAPPENED!" It takes a hold of you and opens your eyes. You feel Ciel's pain and his lust for revenge and you want to skin his enemies alive because you begin to hate them with the same fury that he does.You pick up little things, like how Sebastian seems to really care for Ciel though he would never admit it, or how Elizabeth uses her perkiness to hide her real despair. You're entranced and want to know what happens next, you squeak and squeal when ever anything DOES happen, you fall in love with the characters, you scream when it hits you that you finished watching the entire series.


It's just like... there's not even a word for it. This show that was meant for entertainment suddenly becomes a psychological wonderland that gets you thinking and question your very existence.The philosophy in it makes you wonder and ponder, it grabs your attention and makes you think hard about what religion and justice and death really are.


Before you know it, you are watching what has to be the most complex, complicated, unique masterpiece on earth.


Ciel Phantomhive. He makes my heart ache. With his brutal past, I can totally understand why he's such a killjoy. You know what? He has every right to be a killjoy. No one can go through what he has and not have that right. He's devoted his life to finding the sadistic murderer of his parents, even making a deal with a demon to sell his soul. He's also the emotionally strongest character I have ever come across, in books, movies, animes, mangas, and everything else you can think of. Instead of moping and being depressed, he uses his loathing as armor, to totally shield him from things that would make normal people cry. My absolute favorite quote of his is, "No. I won’t abandon my hatred. If I do, nothing would be left of me." Which is absolutely true.


The other characters all have their own personalities as well. Not a single one of them was boring, dull, a piece of cardboard. Even the enemies (Drocell, for example) are alive with feeling and emotion. None of them are alike. They're all different and various, but magnificent all the same.


The enemies were simply chilling. The doll house especially. None of them are cheesy and fake and laughable. In fact, a few of them seriously freak me out. Not in a disgusting gory way, but in an intimidating creepy way.


Even though this anime is 95% dark, there is humor in it. Most of this is from Grell, the main comedic relief, but there's also Sebastian and the servants who are funny. I grinned like a moron through most their scenes, catching all of the subtle jokes and sarcasm throughout the series. 


To this day, I'm still not sure if Grell is a boy or a girl.


One last thing to gush about while I'm at it: The muuuuuusic! Kuroshitsuji 1 and 2 have the most beautiful soundtrack I've heard since Vampire Knight. There are amazing creepy songs like "The Doll House," hilariously quirky ones like "Die Hasen!"("The Rabbit"), and depressing ones that make you want to bawl your eyes out like "Si deus me Relinquit" ("If God leaves me"). In fact, I'm listening to these songs on Youtube as I write this. They're diverse and vary in styles, genres, and even languages: German, Latin, English, Indian, etc. Though I don't think there are any Japanese lyrics.


All in all, I am so freaking in love with this anime that this long explanatory review doesn't even begin to cover it. You will be impressed. You just have to give it time to morph into this mysterious philosophical being that it is. You will be left slack-jawwed and begging for more. You'll join all of those lame petitions for a season 3. You'll wish you'd watched it sooner.


I promise you won't regret it.







(BTW, I prefer the English dub. Just a recommendation)

I think this anime is severely underrated. Hearing the story synopsis be - demon butler and an heir to a major company make the dynamic duo in England - it didn't appeal to me, but when my friend pressed me to watch it, my views had changed.  
Solving mysteries with a badass demon butler mixed with some comedy, drama and unpredictable plot twists. This is Kuroshitsuji. Ciel and Sebastian are like two sides that make a coin. Ciel has the authoritive yet passive demeanor and Sebastian has the cool, badass style which balances this character development out. 
As for storyline - it is yourgeneral "Same thing different people, different day" In the fact that they solve mysteries episode to episode BUT .. BUT BUT BUT! They all have significance, and not at all do they feel like fillers. In one way or another  they develop on the story or characters in each episode and in solving these mysteries they become one step closer to solving the overall mystery that we are in for. All season I was wishing for that little tug on Ciel's part that shows he really did care for Sebastian more than just a butler. Did I get that satisfaction.. well you can find out for yourself xD If there is anything thaty dissapointed me in this show, it would be the lack of screen time (action wise) for Chef and the other two musketeers.\n\n
Definitely find the time for Black Butler,  it's an anime that every anime watcher must see!

Kuroshitsuji is a well - known manga / anime series that I always wanted to watch because I like so much the whole gothic and Victorian England scenery. Let's start then ... 
  Firstly, I gave a 10 to the story. I know that there are many complaints about the fillers but even that episodes are funny. Also, I'm kinda disappointed that they part ways with the manga and choose a different path but I'm glad that they adapt their story well and they gave a proper conclusion to Ciel's story. Honestly, my favourite parts were the Jack the Ripper arc andthe finale !\n
  The soundtrack is also perfect and so much fitting to the anime , but the real masterpiece is the opening ! Monochrome no kiss is one of the best anime openings I have ever heard and I love how they used the second part of the song for the last part of the season.  The visual part of the openings were also perfect and teasing for the next part of the anime. The endings were very good but I prefered Lacrimosa , since it fits so much with the tone of that episodes. As for the voice actors they have done marvelous job especially Daisuke Ono, Maaya Sakamoto and Jun Fukuyama !\n
  Furthermore, the characters were so much well written that you could easily relate to them. That applies mostly in Ciel's case, where we had seen him grow so much as a character. About the secondary characters, maybe they didn't have so much screen-time to evolve, but there are many all time classics like Grell , Undertaker and even Lau ! \n
  Lastly, for the enjoyment, I had a great time watching this anime. Many fans may prefer the manga [and I will certainly check it] but I believe that they should also give a chance to the anime !

Kuroshitsuji( Black Butler ),an anime that i finished it very quickly.. And this means that I liked it and pretty curious to see what happened next.
Honestly and personally, I liked the 1st season more than the others, and I think that the last one, which is The Book Of Circus, is the worst.. I found it boring.
I adore Sebastian,which is Ciel's butler.. But I dislike how Sebastian treated almost all the time Ciel,I mean, I hoped in a better relationship between them
Anyway, is not a bad show, I recommend it because it's interesting 😊
P.S It's prettier because the anime is set in the victorian-era, ifounded the clothes very beautiful too,especially the Ciel ones!

Kuroshitsuji - or Black Butler as it's called in English speaking countires - is a pretty okay anime adaptation of Yana Toboso's incredible work. Since the manga is not finished, it does try to make up it's own conclusion to the series. 
STORY (spoilers ahead, skip if you wish)- Everything follows a similar path to Yana's original work for a large majority aside from certain episodes (and arc endings) that are changed to fit the anime only finale. My only big problem that makes me go "it's okay" is that the queen of England is behind Ciel's parents murders. Sure ya know it's a incrediblyinteresting idea to have the woman Ciel had worked for be the one to kill his parents but the reasoning behind everything she did feels lazily written. Yes, the stuff with her husband is sad (and what she does is disgusting) but i don't understand that status quo ending where she becomes a normal elderly woman again. Why make her look like a child as well? I doubt she wanted to look young, she just wanted her husband back. I suppose they did that so people would be like "prettyyyyy~" and wouldn't think she did anything wrong when i think it's less suspicious if she was still a elderly woman. Angela/Ash made no sense to me either. Their motivations feel incredibly murky. Were they kicked out of Heaven? Why can they change genders? Why did they want to make a pact with a demon when they clearly despise? Sebastian leaving Ciel felt.....just really desperate to get Ciel his motivation back too. 


ART- Unlike it's second season, the art quality is very high for this. They did a fantastic job recreating Yana's art style and the coloring is both dark yet beautiful choices in palette. The backdrops are stunning at how detailed they are. Even different times of days have incredible colors. My only complaint is i noticed some character's colors were changed from the manga (Mei-Rin's dress being dark blue instead of black). I'll explain my thoughts on the characters later but i do enjoy the designs of everyone. My favorite is Drocell's design (even if he does look like Joker suspicious, funny as the circus arc did start around the time of the first anime's production right?) 


SOUND - Both the English dub and Japanese versions acting is pretty good! With the English dub I would say some actors didn't try hard with their accents (Bardroy and Drocell didn't do well to me). I do prefer the English dub over the Japanese for this series so i don't have many comments to make about the original version. The music is good as well, incredible orchestral sounds! I would say that sometimes i heard rock music or something like that in the show and i don't think that fits the tone of Black Butler. The other music matches Black Butler's refined yet exciting aesthetic while the rock feels honestly pretty over done in comparison. The intro is pretty good, a classic opening song. The ending ones are good too, though i find I'M ALIVE is maybe a little unfitting for Black Butler mostly due to it's beat? That's just me, of course i absolutely adore the song. 


CHARACTERS - As i say in story, i feel like The Queen, Angela and Ash are lacking here. Pluto felt like a BIG out of character moment for everyone involved in Black Butler. I get they wanted a character who was cool and funny but a demon wolf that turns into a man? That doesn't work out for me. It doesn't help that no one questions it too much, not even guests seem to question a giant wolf in their garden! I'd have explain this in story but this mostly feels fitting for character. Of course the original characters of Yana like Sebastian, Ciel, Finnian, Grell, Madam Red, etc are fantastically written. Though, i do feel like Grell was unnecessary in a lot of arcs. She feels like she was kinda put in lazily like a fan fiction for Black Butler, maybe less Grell would have been for the best. I also feel like Lau was incredibly OOC in this one as well. He is a snake and has a opium den, but i doubt he'd try to start another war especially after having seen the horrors of it first hand judging by the backstory he had. Now, the Queen feels really strange for me. Yes, it is natural for her to feel misery after her husband died but how broken did she have to be to let a angel sew her husband's corpse onto her and make her look like she's Ciel's age? None of that makes any sense and feels like they had a lot of trouble. Angela/Ash is also one that feels lazily written and could've used a better explanation. Why couldn't they have made them angel TWINS? I imagine the battle would've been even crazier if we watched Sebastian battle twin angels and take them down without breaking a sweat. It also makes it confusing as to which one is the real gender, is Angela or Ash the real one? Drocell, who appeared in that strange ring arc, was okay. He felt much like if you sucked the life out of Joker from the manga/2nd anime's second arc. Aberline was so far from his manga counterpart though, it's ridiculous and interesting at the same time.  It was nice to have him act as a sort of father figure to Ciel as not even in the manga do we see that, but i don't appreciate what they did with him as a whole.


Overall Black Butler is a really enjoyable anime. This was the first anime i watched that wasn't considered for children in America (as before this the only anime I had seen was Yu Gi Oh, Digimon and Pokemon) so there is a lot of childhood nostalgia for it as well. However, looking back many plot elements didn't age well for me.

Before taking an anime hiatus, the name "Black Butler" seemed to keep popping up everywhere I went. From fan art to posters and symbols, the name had been etched into my mind before I even got anywhere close to watching this show.   
Seeing how boring my summer actually was, I decided to go back to watching anime and the name Black Butler was the first thing that came to my mind. After doing a quick Google search, I saw a bored kid with a weird eyepatch (was this show about classy sassy pirates?), and also skimmed through the description of the first episode(which involved a servant trying to cook a guest he had just put in the oven). Already, this show was starting to look not only pretty wacky, but also strangely morbid and disturbing , so I almost didn't go through with watching it, but hey, anything's better than going out and melting under the scorching summer sun.


Having already developed a bit of a negative bias towards this anime, I wasn't really  expecting to enjoy it, let alone fall in love with it, but then again, falling in love is always something unexpected. After overcoming my initial surprise about how funny and pleasant this show actually was, I noticed some other positive aspects such as the art, the music, the voice acting, and, of course - the interesting characters and the intricate story. 


Since I was already attracted by the compelling premise involving the whole deal-with-the-devil theme, I was pretty much ecstatic when I found out that the show was set in Victorian England. Having already fallen in love with Ashita no Nadja many years ago precisely because of its European setting and enchanting depictions of period costumes and architecture, I knew that Kuroshitsuji would not disappoint in this aspect. 


Surprisingly, the art not only met my expectations, but also exceeded them by far. Besides the lavish architecture and costumes, the colors used were also very aesthetically pleasing and sophisticated. Furthermore, the use of so much color was in itself unexpected for an anime constantly dealing with death, demons, and general creepiness. 


Another thing which I didn't expect for such a PG-13 show was the amount of blood involved. Although it was nowhere near the pointless and ridiculous gore of Elfen Lied, it did "come out" quite often and there were even some random flying limbs involved every now and then, but hey, I guess it was all for the sake of art. 


Nevertheless, the attention to details like the intricate patterns on the tea sets and cutlery as well as the wrinkles on shoe laces and bows made every moment of this show gorgeous and memorable.


However, what would a pretty setting and detailed backgrounds be without dynamic characters and an interesting story? (Well, probably Sword Art Online, but that's not the topic right now).


Besides being beautifully designed and animated, almost all the characters also happen to have interesting backstories, odd quirks, and very unique personalities . Although the protagonist could easily be summarized as a bit of an immature brat who only wants revenge (and doesn't even know how to tie his own shoelaces), the reality is that Ciel is far more complex than that. From a traumatic past to a depressing near future featuring his imminent death as well as a chaotic present, you can definitely see why he behaves the way he does and why he would make a deal with a demon. 


Although even less is known about this demon than his current master,  he still manages to convey a strong and cunning personality which not only seduces and charms everyone around him within the anime, but also many of those who watch it from "the outside" (after all, he was named the top male anime character and best "husbando" at least two years in a row. Or something like that).


However, it's not just the individual personalities and backstories (or lack thereof) of the two main characters which make this show so appealing, but also their relationship. Although it is meant to be that of a master and butler (or servant, if one were to simplify), having the latter be after the former's soul makes it difficult to decide who controls and overpowers who. Additionally, this dark butler also acts as a chef, teacher, companion, and anything else his master might require, which sometimes makes him look more like a caretaker or parent figure rather than a purely evil demon. (This is further reinforced by the fact that the MC is an orphan who has been living without much love and affection for quite some time).


While this relationship is both very difficult to define and extremely entertaining to observe, there are of course other characters, relationships, and interactions which also come into play and make the story all the more interesting. From cross-dressing shinigami (or Death Gods) to the Queen of England, this anime has everything to take you on a wild ride while making you laugh and cry along the way. 


Furthermore, the characters are not only brought to life through the power of beautiful art and animation, but also through that of amazing voice acting. Although Daisuke Ono is in a class of his own and uses one of the sultriest and most beautiful voices I have ever heard in anime for his role as Sebastian, other seiyuu like Fukuyama Jun and Hiroki Yasumoto also never fail to surprise and delight with their equally impressive vocal ranges and amazing performances. The success of the Kuroshitsuji seiyuu events as well as the awards won by Ono-D for his work in this show should therefore come as no surprise. (What does come as a surprise, however, is the fact that a vacuuming robot featuring phrases by Sebastian Michaelis was actually being sold in Japan. Guess there are people who are even more obsessed with Ono-D's voice than I am, huh). 


For the record, I also tried to check out the English dub but this was very brief since I simply couldn't stand Ciel sounding like a whiny, constipated little girl. Although he is voiced by a girl in Japanese too, he doesn't sound as one as much as he does in English. Sebastian, on the other hand, sounds pretty great with an (unfortunately fake) English accent as do the other characters. Having a special (though also fake) accent for the Indian characters was also appreciated since they didn't get one in Japanese. 


Besides the fabulous voice acting of the main and supporting cast, another great aspect of this anime (which also happens to be really underrated) is definitely the music. Although Yuki Kajiura didn't compose the soundtrack for this show, her band Kalafina is featured  repeatedly and makes a beautiful addition to all the other music used in Kuroshitsuji. Besides Kalafina's Lacrimosa and Becca's "I'm alive" as the ending songs, the opening theme called "Monochrome no Kiss" is also pretty awesome and fits with the overall mood of the show really well. 


However, it is not just these songs which deserve praise and admiration, but also those original ones used as background music throughout the series, such as "La gardenia" and "Die Hasen". Although I personally think it would have made more sense to use more songs in English since this anime is actually, well, set in England, I think that the music director did a wonderful job in incorporating not only different European languages into the soundtrack but also some more classical and darker vibes. Besides German, English, and Italian, the show also features songs in Latin and Hindi as well as themes reminiscent of Gregorian chants. Consequently, this makes the anime feel, if not entirely English, then at least very sombre, European and Victorian. Despite the bad pronunciation by some of the artists who sung the songs in German and Latin, the Japanese tenor who was hired to sing the songs in Italian has an impeccable accent and makes them sound, if not entirely like opera, then at least like classical crossover or operatic pop. This makes Black Butler the perfect combination of modern and Victorian, hence overall timeless and cosmopolitan.


Although it may not be everyone's cup of tea, Black Butler is a beautiful and unique anime that is definitely worth watching. Whether it be for the original story and wonderful characters, the gorgeous art, animation, and music, or the random quirky humor, it has something for everyone and is therefore difficult to define or categorize simply as "another shounen show". For me, the only problem was how creepy and disturbing the anime got towards the end, but since it is likely that this was what the creators had originally intended, then this should probably count as a strength rather than a weakness. 

Consequently, while Kuroshitsuji may not be THE best show I have ever seen in my life, it is certainly ONE of them and therefore holds a very special place in my heart and soul  (as well as my MAL favorites, of course). If you're asking yourself whether you should watch Black Butler, then, in the words of Sebastian Michaelis, all I can say is "Yes, My Lord."

Although the first season of Black Butler (Kuroshitsuji) sort of serves as an icebreaker for the seasons after, it still counts, as it isn't simply a pilot but an entire season. Therefore, I must acknowledge it.
It's difficult to explain how I feel about the first season of Black Butler. I was very entertained by it, but it was almost as if there was more comic relief than any actual story. During the first season almost everything was done to try and make the viewer laugh, which was nice but not nice enough to save the season. 
The story isn't bad, but the problem is thatthere isn't really a story in the first place. Black Butler stars a young boy named Ciel Phantomhive who is the earl of the Phantomhive family and his butler, who is a demon named Sebastian Michaelis. (In case you didn't know, Black Butler is set in the time of the Victorian Era.) Ciel forms a contract with Sebastian in order to get revenge on the people who have soiled the Phantomhive name, and to get revenge on the person who burned down his mansion and caused the death of his parents--although he doesn't know who this person is yet. 


But the story, for some odd reason, doesn't seem to be centered on that, at least not during the first season. Sure, Ciel brings it up all the time, but the situations he gets involved in don't usually have to do with exacting his revenge, which is strange. Also, remember how I earlier said that this season doesn't really have a story? I'm going to bring that up again. Every episode of this season there's a different problem. Each problem is resolved at the end of its episode. However, these problems would definitely not realistically be resolved in such a short amount of time. Additionally, most of these problems appear to be either randomized or extremely unlikely. 


Another thing I'd like to acknowledge is that the characters are pretty much two-dimensional. And to be fair, that's usually what characters are until the second season or, in some cases, even later. But besides Sebastian being a badass and Ciel having the personality of a bratty (yet badass) rebel and the capability of a nine-year-old, the characters don't really have anything else about them. The rest of the characters are so toned down that I can't really say much about them besides "comic relief." 


I would just like to let anyone who is reading this and is agitated know that I actually do like Black Butler, very much. Although I've been mostly bringing up this season's issues (and indeed I believe this season was definitely not the best season Black Butler had), I don't dislike Black Butler at all. It just doesn't seem overly special, at least not by this point, and I will post a review for the second season, since I've also watched that. The story isn't overly unique (if there's a story at all). 


But here are some good points about this season of Black Butler. The art and animation is very good. There's nothing to complain about there. The quality of the anime itself (rather than the story, characters, etc.) is incredibly satisfactory. Don't let this review turn you off from starting Black Butler; there are many people who like it more than I do, and I'm just one opinion. I hope this helped!

Kuroshitsuji
*No Spoilers*
Summary: 
            Ciel phantomhive, a young boy who has lost his mother and father in a terrible fire. Later Ciel summons the demon Sebastian Michaelis to be his butler, help him with his missions, and protect him. This gripping anime is about Ciel and Sebastian solving mysteries and going through the life of a young English aristocrat.
Pros:
* first of all, the artwork is amazing and sort of reminiscent of Tim Burton's creepy drawing style. It's dark and beautiful all at once.
* Well Developed characters. you quickly fall in love with and care foreach character very quickly.


* the action scenes are entertaining and not too much to watch.


*The mysteries are compelling and leaves you needing to know what happens next. 


*The world is well-developed,  beautifully drawn, and easy to understand how this world works. 


*the Japanese dub is beautiful. (Sebastian's voice tho) the English dub isn't too bad. however, the acting isn't as good with English. but both voices were equally pretty similar to each other.


* The accuracy to the way Englishmen dress and act are pretty well executed in this anime.


*Love the theme song for both series'


* I love the dark humor in this show. I laughed way too hard with some of the jokes.


Cons:


*  Violence and gore are everywhere in this anime. So, if you can't handle blood, guts, or implied rape. This anime wouldn't be for you. The blood is more prevalent than the sexual violence.


* if you are religious, you may feel uncomfortable with things Sebastian does. I'm religious and the things that happen somethings were very uncomfortable to watch. there are angels and demons in this anime but their role is opposite, demons are good and angels are evil. There are lots of demonic imagery, such as pentagrams.


* Does get slow in some places.

black butler is BY FAR one of my favorite anime of all time. i absolutely love the concept of demons/grim reapers and a child taking over as the earl of his family's estate. i love the time setting of victorian era england where earls and nobles make up the majority of the monarchy. but trust me- that's not the only thing that has brought be back to this series so many times.
black butler may just be the most well-written anime series i've seen. it doesn't have the lazy, shortcut type of writing that's just there to fill in the gaps, rather, it builds different storiesthat supports different themes but ultimately leads up to the same goal: to find the people who killed ciel's parents.


the themes of revenge and redemption are knitted together so perfectly with yana toboso's well-crafted storylines. though this isn't an anime with nonstop action, it has its share of dark battle scenes but also with dark, witty, humorous battle scenes. it has quite a bit of dark humor, but also a unique sense of humor throughout the series that never fails to make me laugh.


overall, this anime never fails to bring a smile to my face or tears to my eyes with its shocking scenes and backstory, or its dark humor. if you don't think you'll like it after watching the first episode, KEEP WATCHING! it breaks off from the manga around episode 15 or so, but it's still good after that.

Black Butler is one of my favorite animes at the moment.
The story is based on Victorian England. The Characters are very well designed, voiced and much more. 
I loved the plot, the characters. Especlity when Sebby always says 'I'm simply, one HELL of a butler.' This anime is very dramatic, I always cry every time whilst watching a episode. The end to this season 1 is very dramatic and sad. 
I got really into Black Butler, but slowly started to get bored a tiny bit. But it always cheers me up. Some of the characters in this show are based on real life people duringthe Victorian times. \n\n
This anime is very historical, dramatic and sad. The only thing I disliked about this anime that some of the backgrounds are lacking with color. But it's ok, but I wouldn't say it's too great.\n\n

I don't even know where to start with this. What kind've shit did I just watch? I have sorrow upon my poor eyes that had to suffer through 19 FUCKING EPISODES of this mess. I practically choked on my bagel when watching this, especially after hearing the praise some people gave it. I can't even write a proper review on this, it's so bad. 
I am convinced that anybody whom rates this anime above a 4, is a troll. I feel as if this is the goblin of all anime; I feel as if I just watched Skelter+Heaven II. This is essentially watching Kim Kardashianin an alternate universe; dreadful, a prissy bitch and their servant, and a "dark past" that caused them to do all this shit. I mean sure, that's a dark past, but holy fuck we don't even know the full details of it. We don't even know who exactly caused it all. \n\n
I feel as if I need therapy after watching this and hearing some people rate it good. The only good thing about it is Grell's weave. If you are a masochist and enjoy suffering, this anime is for you.

Anime has such a lack of original and really great characters. So many cookie-cutter types out there. Super serious, spikey haired, bad-asses. Tough and heavy chested tomboys. Magic girls. Yada yada yada. "Black Butler" comes along and gives you a good show with a great character in the lead, Sebastian Michaelis- the titular black butler and an original concept to go with it.
Setting in Victorian, turn of the century, England, "Black Butler" gives us a great enviornment of stately mansions, the streets of London right out of Sherlock Holmes, and all the mystery and intrigue one might expect of such a location. Throw in asupernatural element involving a demon butler, reapers, angels, and Faustian covenants (that's fancy talk for a deal with the Devil) and you get one helluva an Anime.


The art is pretty impressive at times and the soundtrack is full of classical-derived tunes and melodramatic, dark, choirs. They throw in humor, action, horror, drama and mix it all together for a splendid time in 24 episodes. Sub vs. Dub is a big fight here. The Japanese cast does the best job, but the English cast (doing their best English accents) gives the show the most authenticity. Daisuke Ono and J. Michael Tatum both own the role of Sebastian in Japanese and English, respectively. Honorable mentions go to Daniel Frederick as Grell Sutcliff (absolutely hilarious) in English and Junichi Suwabe as Undertaker in Japanese. Some really good performances on both sides here.


I really enjoyed this show. Sebastian Michaelis stands out as one of my favorite characters of all-time. I love the time period and everything that goes with it. It's a really great show and very unique. Anime fans should consider this a must-watch.

Ok. This is my first time writing a review, so I don't know what to say.
I decided to write it because this is my favourite anime and I'd like to say the reasons of why I´m so proud of this masterpiece.

Well. Honestly, where do I begin with Black Butler? This anime left me with so many mixed emotions I simply can't make sense of it all. 
I'll start with the positives, I suppose. These positives being what kept me watching despite the negatives. Most significantly: The art. This show is gorgeous. Though I won't lie and say many of the angles and styles aren't reminiscent of yaoi and BL, I also couldn't say that the animation was bad, or anywhere near. I particularly loved the outfit design. Especially Ciel's outfits, the main character. Well, not counting the dress. 
I also enjoyed the characters, especially Ciel.While in some cases he did seem like a pretty obvious fanservice character (and a thinly veiled definitely-not-shota), I liked him regardless. He's an incredibly stubborn character, which is frustrating, though I'd say that ultimately it's a frustration that adds to the experience of watching the show. Sebastian is a bit bland, but honestly, it would kind of spoil his character if he had any real depth. 


Now, the negatives. 


Well, the story premise is quite interesting. A ten year old boy who makes a deal with a literal demon, trading his soul for revenge? It's a great setup, but it all honesty it falls completely flat.


Most of the episodes are filler, and consist of little battles to be fought that are never brought up again and serve no purpose to the overall story. Sometimes they're enjoyable, sometimes they're boring, but none of them are very satisfying. When the plot finally does kick in, it's fascinating! 


But... it's also rushed, and confusing. Episode 24 left me with more questions than answers, especially with episode 25 completely ignoring what happened right before. I don't know if that's only true of the Netflix edition, but it was frustrating and confusing regardless. 


Ultimately, do I recommend this anime? Yes. 


Will I be watching season 2? Absolutely. 


Why do I recommend it? It's enjoyable. Especially for anyone into guys. There's also some LGBT content--and I don't just mean the vague yaoi stuff. There's two characters hinted (well, more than hinted--it's pretty much confirmed) to be transgender. No spoilers, though. 


Why will I be watching season 2? I've been roped in by these characters. I care about Ciel. For anyone who gets overly invested in emotional characters, I can almost guarantee this anime is for you in that regard.

Kuroshitsuji, or Black Butler, whichever you prefer, was a pretty good anime. It was the first anime I've ever watched and I'd like to say that it was a good choice. It was really good, but not too good to where I'd have expectations too high for other anime in the future. 
I'l start with the story for this review. The main protagonist of this anime, Ciel Phantomhive, is a twelve (later thirteen) year old earl living in London, England with his butler, Sebastian Michaelis, who happens to be a demon. (and a Gary Stu) Ciel made a contract with him when he was tenand during a terrible moment of his life. I can't say much more without any spoilers. 


The art of this anime was really good and the animation was very fluent and smooth. (mostly) It also had some very good, sometimes catchy, songs in it's OST. The theme song was actually stuck in my head for months after I finished this season!


The characters are mostly good in the anime, but because this was an anime and didn't directly follow the manga, the anime obviously didn't have as much character development as the manga did. But it did have some character development, especially near the end.


Ciel is a very relate-able and likable character, probably the most likable out of all of them. You will feel for him when seeing his darkest moments and you'll also understand his bitterness, which is a mere coating for him to mask his feelings that leave him vulnerable. Sebastian is also likable but not relate-able, so he's lower on the scale of favorites for me than Ciel.


One character that I particularly did not like was Elizabeth. I loved her in the manga, but in the anime she was flat out annoying. Maybe it was her high pitched voice, girly attitude, or her glomping Ciel who clearly hates it that made me hate her. 


I enjoyed this anime a lot and it had a nice ending besides the fact that the ending didn't have a reason. Overall I'd rate 7/10. I recommend this for fans of fantasy for sure though, because of the angels, demons, reapers, and more.

Unlike other "dark" animes, I consider this one of the darkest I've seen. What other show has a demon butler, a 13 year old boy seeking revenge, an angel as the main enemy, and a 14 year old snob drowning in his own greed? Whether this   anime has some humerous moments, it is obvious that funny is not what the creator intended for this original masterpiece. I thought it was slow at the beginning of both seasons, however, the plot line quickly picked up pace and thus, the story of Ciel Phantomhive became one of my favorites. It is definitely not an animeI would recommend for those looking for action/suspense/thriller. Yes, there are a handful of duels and its share of blood baths, but the plot line has more of a conceptual focus rather than a physical action focus. I loved the consistency of this anime. Famous quotes are always repeated, and the characters even have their signature gestures that make them unique and real. After all, what kind of anime would it be if they weren't?\n\n
I highly recommend this anime to those looking to think outside the box ;)

To tell the truth, I haven't finished this, but that's because I'm a wimp and I like happy endings with flowers and butterflies (you can tell from the first episode that there aren't any flowers or butterflies here). I'm on episode 12 and I've read summaries of the other episodes. Some parts make me uncomfortable, it's very dark, and when watching this, I almost feel a sense of boredom.
The story is rather original and the plot is well thought out. It is very deep and dark, nothing for the faint-hearted. I love the mystery and the bits of foreshadowing, good stuff. I gave it a9, because the ending isn't very complete (I haven't watched it, but that's what I get from secondary sources).


I liked the art. The animation was really good, and I loved Ciel's attire. I did think that Sebastian's lips were too sharp, and he looked a little bit TOO evil sometimes (I guess it's to be expected, he is a demon). There was WAY too much blood for my liking, but maybe it was necessary. I gave it a 9.


I think that the music suited the anime very well, and caught the dark tones. The music set the mood well, but I think they used the tune of "London Bridge Is Falling Down," way too much. I never liked that song. I gave it an 7.


The characters were OK. Ciel was interesting, but it unnerved me that he acted so old at the age of 12. Elizabeth annoyed me, because her overwhelming carefree attitude (yes yes she was sad because Ciel was sad, it's devastating), contrasted drastically with Ciel's dark depth. The servants at the mansion were mostly used for comic relief, which also annoyed me. Sebastian's almighty-ness got to me when he was in the ice-carving contest. My favorite character was Grell, but I liked the Undertaker, and Pluto was quite adorable (as a human). At episode 12, I haven't seen much character development. I gave it a 7.


I did enjoy the series, but after hearing so much of London Bridge in episode 11 and 12, and Grell having left without spending a day with Sebastian, I'm putting this on hold. After I read the summaries for the rest of the episodes, I'm thinking about abandoning this, not because it's not enjoyable, but I'm really not into dark plots. I gave enjoyment an 8 because, well, watching this made me unhappy, because of how dark this is. The comic relief provided by the servants almost seemed out of place. 


Overall, I gave this a 7. I guess the total was less than the sum, but it was probably the feeling of indifference that I felt when watching this that made it so. I was a complete fan girl when Grell was there, and the Undertaker made me cackle, but other than that, and I couple of laughs and giggles, I didn't feel much for this. I had a problem with a 12 year old giving away his soul. I would recommend it if you like this kind of thing. People die in this, people are unhappy, no one can be trusted (except those comic relief characters), and almost everyone has a tragic past, it's a good series.

*STORY* - 8/10 - Like most anime, Kuroshitsuji contains some overly dramatic scenes where not much drama is needed however, it is redeemed by touching scenes with just the right amount of drama. The sub-plots' of this anime have the tendency to run like filler as the series progresses on, that's not to say that they are all bad but, for example, one that involves Indians and curry seems to be exeptionally irrelevent to the plot but it manages to suffice to entertain. There are quite a few twists that would have been very difficult to see coming but in the end the new plotdevelopments are convincing and not just random. 


*ART* - 10/10 - The animation of this anime flows beautifully and is not overly cartoonish like most and with the beautiful European setting it makes it all the more outstanding. It is extremely similiar to the animation in Death Note, it might just be the same studio. 


*SOUND* - 9/10 - The music in this anime is quite lovely at times while at other's it seems to stray from the Victorian setting, sounding too modern. But as a whole the music does not overpower the show itself which is what matters more. 


*CHARACTER* - 8/10 - The characters were good but they could have been better with some more development. One in paticular is one of the main characters' Ceil Phantomhive, his parent's death seems to be the only thing which is used to make the child from an innocent well, child, to a cold, hate drivin b******. Another example, Maylene, is just a clumsy maid stereotype. 


*ENJOYMENT* - 8/10 - The anime has a nice mix of a dark /dramatic story and humor, it doesn't leave you desperately waiting for something to break the tension since it is perfectly balanced. It held my interest very well and I rarely was bored. 


*OVERALL* - 9/10 - This anime makes it very easy to twist the relationship of Ciel and Sebastian in a homosexual way (Yaoi). I personally don't have anything against Yaoi but Sebastian happens to be potrayed as an older man while Ciel is a 12 year old kid, it might seem a little creepy to some.

In the beginning, I wasn't sure of what to expect. I typically go for the shojo and romance anime's but I absolutley LOVED Black Butler!!! It was very dark and myterious yet I kept watching more and more because it's so suspensful!
The plot is somewhat intricate. Ciel is a young noble who's parents were killed in a fire and after they died, he was kidnapped and tortured. He then meets Sebastian who is a demon. Sebastian and Ciel form a contract in which Ciel sells his soul to Sebastian so that Sebastian will kill all those who kidnapped and tortured Ciel. Each mission in eachepisode shows each of Sebastians hidden strengths in what he goes through to protect his master, Ciel. Ciel matures much throughout the series and backstories about each member living in the Phantomhive household are revealed. Although this anime is dark, there are quite a few moments where you can't help but laugh.


I watched the Funimation dub and I thought they did an outstanding job with their dub. If anyone has seen Ouran High School Host Club, Sebastian is voiced by the same man who voices Kyouya Ootori. I thought his voice fit perfectly with Sebastians character. Also, if anyone has seen Romeo x Juliet, the lady who voices Juliet does a fabulous job with the voice of Ciel Phantomhive. If anyone has seen Fruits Basket, Lau is voices by the same voice actor as Kyo Sohma!


The art was beautiful, a bit Lolita-esque. The animators really grasped a feeling of this 19th century Victorian time era. The animation is very crisp and clear and the colors are very descriptive help define the characters. 


Overall I completley enjoyed this anime, mainly because you have no idea what to expect! Its story is so different from the rest which makes it so unpredictable. I completley reccomend seeing it, ignore anyone who tells you otherwise!

Kuroshitsuji or Black Butler in English is a work from Toboso Yana. This anime series confused me to what are the rights and wrongs. I can say that this is one of a kind that give it a passionate fans, the demonic kind. However, you will find it amazing and believe me , it really confused me again to whom should I believe  to the demon or to the angel? You know I found the angel there as the villain and the demon the savior! What the hell? Well watch it for yourself.
The demon that I’m saying is a butler, Sebastian Michaelis,the butler ofthe Earl Ciel Pantomhive, or lets just say the demon butler. Sebastian Michaelis is originally a demon, his young master Ciel made a contract to him when he had given a mark of a sin and the one who killed his parents which leaded him to do the said contract to make a revenge on them who made him suffered.\n
The demon butler Sebastian forms a human body, which he needs to socialize to the human world and do his job to his master. He is like a shadow of his young master, whatever may happen he need to obey all the orders that was given to him. It is a must to fullfill even a single order. He sincerely devoted his loyalty to the Earl in exchange for the soul . He will be able to get that soul and body after the mission that Ciel Pantomhive need to finished.\n\n
this review can also be seen in my wordpress\n
irock7444.wordpress.com

This is a very good anime, I enjoyed it very well. Don't be fooled, at first I thought there was no real plot, but it was an extremily well thought out plot, as it turns out. The anime is a little dark, and ciel's butler seems very sinister, so it kind of felt like there was a thing between ciel and his butler, although nothing happened. So if you don't like that kind of stuff, then don't watch it. Very enjoyable characters, but the end was kind of depressing. Every character had a background that the show elaborated on, but not too much that itwent away from the original story. I'd say though if you get depressed easily, don't watch it, at least not to the very end.  I hope you'll like it as much as I did. ^^

I thought this anime was really interesting. At first, you can see how Sebastian and Ciel meet and then it shows you what the two are really capable of. Then, there are a few twists added in. 
The first one is when you meet a blue haired girl in one of the episodes. Then, you see that the queen has a butler that looks similar to her. The two play a surprisingly important part and if you've watched the whole first season, you know exactly what happened. 
The end was, of course, the most exciting part. You know exactly why the queen never showed upout of the castle, who the girl and boy are, and how well Sebastian really does as a demon and a butler. It ties the whole thing together in a really exciting way. You can also see what Ciel would do if Sebastian wasn't around.

Where do I start talking about perfection? It's so hard to talk about it. The story is set in Victorian England (XIX century) * - * The plot involves demons, contracts, angels, death gods among other eccentricities. Ciel Phantomhive, a 13 year-old is a young (too young) boss of family. He had his dead parents in a fire in Phantomhive Mansion, and was forced to join a cult. Struck a deal with a demon, contract in which, Ciel gave his soul in exchange for carrying out his revenge. This demon was appointed by Ciel as "Sebastian Michaelis," his current butler who was in charge oftaking care of his revenge, so after realizing it, his soul is ready to be eaten. Ciel also has the title "The Dog of Queen ", it takes care of the issues "dirty"  in the crown with the help of his more than perfect butler, who performs flawlessly and the top speed the orders of his  master . A fabulous character appears later in the anime, just do not talk about it, because I do not like giving spoilers. Ciel has a style of "dark hero", which attracts me. He "fight" for their ideals, and that revenge is carried out; Machiavelli: The ends justify the means. That is, everything he does, even kill a inocete, is justified by its thirst for revenge. The anime does not have a boring air of "happily ever after", which also pleases me, because it makes it more unpredictable.

I'm going to be truthful here: I liked this anime, a lot. But I can't be clear on why.
The story was good. I mean, parts of it were REALLY good, and parts of it were... confusing at best. I didn't know what the main plot was about until 5/6 episodes (I don't remember exactly). While interesting as a mystery show meanwhile, it didn't really caught my interest until the main plot was revealed. Afterwards, I was quite hooked. So I gave it a solid 8/10.
The art was the thing that drew me to the series in the first place. It's very pretty, to be frank,and I might be falling short with an 8/10. I really liked the character designs.


The sound was quite interesting in itself. It complemented the show very well. Another solid 8/10.


The characters... I'm not sure. While maybe I'm not a fan of Sebastian, the other characters are well developed. I particularly enjoyed the stories of the Ciel's staff. Each of them had a short but interesting back story. A 7/10 is fitting.


Enjoyment, 8/10. Like I said, I didn't really became hooked until after the main plot is shown. Otherwise it was really enjoyable, except for a few moments of unnecessary shota undertones. I'm not really interested in that and found it a bit creepy sometimes. I might be biased though, because, after the art, the thing that made me watch it was the dark Victorian-age London setting. I loved it.


Overall 8/10.

I really enjoyed this anime, and even started re-watching it a few times. If you like this anime, you should also read the manga to it, it's much better and it's not the exact same. The manga and anime stop being linked together around episode 9. And don't forget, if you haven't watched season 2, do so. They changed the director for it though so it's a little more dark than before.

The beauty and elegance that the characters, environment and overall animation hold will sweep anyone off of their feet at first glance. And it’s surely certainly enough to keep one enticed. But let’s step back and look at it critically for a moment and discuss the good and the bad.
The Bad: -Kuroshitsuji essentially doesn’t have much of a plot. You get a couple hints of it at the beginning, so you get some idea of what it is. However, for most of the anime you watch many filler arcs that - while entertaining – are not related to the plot {for the most part}.The anime gets really intense about 6 {estimating} episodes before the end, and it felt a little rushed.


- It’s a little unrealistic. A friend of mine and I were discussing it, and we realized that no one – passersby, other servants, etc – stopped to look at Sebastian and go “holy balls, your eyes are red, you should get that looked at” and suspected him of being supernatural.


- Kuroshitsuji was a yaoi tease the whole time. I would be lying if I said that the relationship between Sebastian and Ciel wasn’t borderline homoerotic. Now, Yana Toboso also created a yaoi before making Kuroshitsuji {Rust Blaster}. So she had full intentions of making Yaoi puns and teasers. However, there are no “successful” yaoi scenes. If you’re the type that can’t stand to be teased, with pretty people, then this might bother you a little more than it should.






The Good: - It’s pretty. I don’t know what else I can say about it. The people are pretty, the scenery is pretty, the way everyone and everything moves is beautiful. It’s definitely one thing that keeps you watching


- Yana Toboso did her research. Most of the characters followed the fashion of Victorian England, and while I can’t remember some little specifics that pertained to the setting, they were pretty accurate. It’s nice to know that there are artists that don’t portray history obscenely.


- It’s actually quite comedic. Almost all of the characters are lovable and mesh well together. I swear, I almost keeled over and died a couple of times because of the ridiculous things that Sebastian does. With most of the plot being filler, it’s something nice to keep around and watch if you don’t know what to watch or have nothing better to do.






My opinion: - Story 7/10: As stated before, most of it was filler, but entertaining. The little plot that was rushed in was original. The idea of a demon serving someone in exchange for their soul isn’t all that common. And all of the servant’s backstories are touching. However, even at the end of the anime, there are some loose ends that they didn’t tie up. Which in turn prompts you to watch Kuroshitsuji II.


- Sound 9/10: Musically speaking, it has a classical/jazzy soundtrack with a dash of Latin choir, which might not appeal to or annoy some people. The soundtrack was actually done by one of my favorite Japanese composers, Taku Iwasaki {Also did the music for Soul Eater}. So I might be a tad biased. But for those who appreciate it, the music is very well put together. As far as the voices go, I cannot stress this enough; DO NOT WATCH DUB, WATCH SUB!!!! While I appreciate the consideration for the fact that they’re in England, the voices don’t match the characters and the British accents are bad, to say the least.


- Characters 10/10: All of the characters are lovable. The two sides to all of the main and secondary characters are a neat twist and come in handy. Yana Toboso really thought them through and gave them good character development, which made a moment when someone was asked to do something out of character all the more comedic. They all have specific traits about them, which make them unforgettable and difficult to mix up with other characters.




If you’re the type that likes to know what’s going on, then you should definitely give this one a chance {I suggest watching it and reading the manga as a paired up project}. It’s for the people that love darker, out of the ordinary plots, and everything Victorian. It’s definitely not cutesy and to say it’s an eyesore would be an insult. Something as entertaining as this deserves more recognition.

I saw Kuroshitsuji during the summer before I even had a MAL account and I was very excited before and after I watched the anime. This amazing anime focuses on what happens when a sexy demon butler slowly yet patiently hunts for his prey. Long story short, Sebastian ends up getting himself into a world of unexpectancies that he never EVER expected. This anime is filled with SO many sexy characters that women and/or men will get wet between the legs over them. Even the blood shed is amazing! Sebastian and Claude give off a  legendary sexiness. They give off so much love andsweet tenderness every time an anime lover watches this anime! The characters in this anime are absolutely perfect. But, the one problem that I had in this anime is that it did not follow the manga at all. I mean it did but, some of the manga that could've been in season one ended up in season two. It really did confused me. *sulks* But, overall the anime was a job well done! I  would keep watching it over and over again until I die in a  delightful grave! If there is anyone looking for a good anime to watch, this is a MUST SEE! \n\n
Arigatou!

SPOILER ALERT FOR BOTH THE ANIME AND THE MANGA!! 
So! I finished the anime a couple of days ago. 
My expectations for this anime were huge! Mainly cuz the manga is one of the best manga series I have ever read, and cuz everyone all over the internet and conventions love it! 
I will be comparing the anime adaptation to the manga in this review! If you don't like me doing that then read another review! You have been warned!!
And btw, I have only watched season 1 since Kuroshitsuji II just seams to stray way too far from the manga to me. 
So what didI think? 

It was such an insult to the characters and the brilliant mangaka that I wanted to throw up! 


THE CHARACTERS 

Ciel is even more bitter in the anime than in the manga. The thing I really like about him is that he is harsh and always stays true to his goal, but he can also lighten up when he is around the right people. In the anime he is just cold! They try to make him a bit caring for Lizzy, but that fails in my book. 


The quarrels between Ciel and Sebastian are pretty much gone. I loved how Ciel tried to get Sebastian on his feet and wanting to see him defeated, and Sebastian would get back at him in some funny way. 


Lizzy is nothing but annoying. In the manga she is really annoying till you get the reason WHY! She gets badass later on! In the anime they never get that far, the only thing she does is to get kidnapped and then so nothing. 


I have many problems with Sebastian as well, but that has to do with the plot, let's get back to that! 


Everyone else are pretty much the same I guess, but they never get the time to develop the characters since they only had 12 episodes. The 3 servants only get 1 episode for their background stories and such. This is really a shame since you never get to fully see how badass they can be or get to hear all of their stories. And what they've done to Tanaka is just weird o_o' he has a time limit to be normal? This didn't really play any part. Most of my favorite characters didn't even make it in. 


THE STORY 

So. . . . . . . NOTHING IS CORRECT HERE!! (Ok maybe the arc with jack the ripper) 

I know that the anime is an adaptation and that changes has to be made, and sometimes I think it's way better that way. But when it ruins the entire plot and the characters all together. . . . NOPE! 


The plot is that an angle have some sort of task to purify Ciel and the world! This ruins pretty much everything, I really don't think that an antagonist is needed to this story. The characters interact in other ways and the story is for a big part out of the picture. The manga is mostly arcs about random stuff that gradually move closer to Ciel's past. Here they felt like they needed a plot with an end to it, so they threw in an angel and ruins the contract! And that was my main problem. They ignores what the contract is! The main point of the series is the bond between Ciel and Sebastian. Sebastian might not like it, but the contract forces him to do anything Ciel says! In the anime the contract has an end of some sort. When his "Goal" (not the same as in the manga) is accomplished Sebastian may take his soul, just like that! Something they mention many times is "I will follow you until death" problem is that here it doesn't seam like it at all. And Ciel isn't fully dead at the end either. Yeah, he dies. . .yeah. . 

The queen is so devastated about her husbands death that she accepts to be purified by the angel and get a younger body that is a mix between hers and her dead husbands bodies. . . .Creepy! I like how she is devastated, but in a fun way in the manga. And not crazy! 


My biggest problem though was close to the end, when Sebastian just ignores the contract, questions and leaves Ciel, and then just does nothing. Honestly, I never cared to listen to why he did that, the only thing is that like I said before, the contract is completely ignored. And then you have to sit through 2 episodes of Ciel being all powerless! He is Earl Phantomhive, he is not supposed to look all powerless! It completely ruined his character. He is vulnerable in the manga too, but he quickly gets stronger again, like he has more determination. 


Like I started out, the arc with Jack the ripper is very well played! It is very beautiful and emotional. I really liked what they did with the cinematic record! The arc after that with the Indian prince -insert name here- and the curry contest was about to be good also! But they ruined it by getting Mina involved. She gets possessed by something and people go nuts. It's not at all as smooth as the event in the manga where the queen shows up to judge the contest, Sebastian winning, the prince getting hurt by Mina hating him, crying his eyes out to Ciel and then they just end it on a happy note! I loved that arc in the manga btw. It was at this point that I started thinking in the anime "Ok, what the heck are they planning to do with this!?" 

The arc with Lizzie and the dolls was so forgettable to me that I, well, forgot about it!


This is all opinion based, as it always is when it comes to anything!


And I know that I completely compare it to the manga, and that might not be fully fair. But the manga is such a masterpiece that it's really hard not too! In all honesty though, I don't think I would have liked the anime even if I had not read the manga. It gets way to confusing and screws way too much with the contract. 


Comparing it too the manga I give it 2/10. It had a very good start, a very confusing and weird middle part and a horrible ending. 


Not comparing it too the manga I give it a 5/10 Some arcs were good, it had beautiful animation and could be very intense! But it still lacks when it comes too keeping the characters up. 


I will now go eat an ice cream. . . cuz I can! 

Thanks for reading, have a good one!

Black Butler was definitely  one of the darkest animes I've watched to date. Since I have nothing else to compare it to I will try to be as fair and impartial as possible (since I do favour comedies and dramas). 
To summarize, Black Butler (Kuroshitsuji) takes place in Victorian-Era Great Britain and stars the young Ciel Phantomhive, whom through the tragic loss of his parents has literally "made a deal with the devil" to seek revenge on those at fault. He strikes a deal with a demon named Sebastien; in exchange for being his right hand man in his journey for revenge, he willgive up his own soul for Sebastien to consume when all is said and done. They work together in investigating cases assigned to them by the Queen while maintaining their true revenge objectives, using anything and anyone to obtain their goals. 


Story: 9/10

The setting made the story quite interesting, as the Victorian era was a time of lots of folklore, making the tales and antics of demons, ghosts and curses absurd but believable. What fascinated me was that the endings of each episode were pretty predictable, but there were many twists and turns along the way that were unexpected. One of my biggest complaints in the first half of the anime was the misplacement of humor or comedy in the middle of serious scenes. It happened very frequently and made those serious moments feel very anticlimactic. The ending is probably one of the best I have seen in any anime as it was something that was not really a surprise but was still filled with excitement, joy and sadness at the same time. This is definitely not a feel good anime and really doesn't show any redeeming qualities for most relationships, often showing betrayal, deception and resentment. But hey, life sometimes dishes that out so its nice to see everything isn't cherry blossoms and sunshine all the time. 


Art/Animation: 10/10

This anime had beautiful art and animation. The character designs were very well done, especially with Sebastien. Maybe it was just me, but he stood out in EVERY scene he was in. Even though it was supposed to be a dark anime, there are times of beautiful bright colors; my favorite scenes actually being when there was snow and sunsets. They gave a particular feeling of warmth which was a nice addition and maybe even break from the dark themes :) 


Characters: 9.5/10

Ciel and Sebastien are a great team and their relationship both confused and fascinated me. Ciel at times could be quiet annoying but he is a 12-year rich kid so it was to be expected :p. Sebastien is one of the most complex characters I have ever seen. He often made me forget what his true motives were as he seemed devote and loyal. But after episode 17 you truly see he will DO ANYTHING to obtain his goal and it was disturbing to see (which I think was the point). I can't help liking him despite his motives which probably is a reflection of his good looks but also his interactions with the servants in the home who act as the comedic relief. All of the servants were likable, my favorite being Tanaka :D Such a cute old man!! The only characters I disliked (whom we were supposed to actually like) was Lizzie, Ciel's fiancée, whom I thought was truly annoying in most cases. 


Sound: 8/10

The opening and ending themes were great and the second half of the anime did have themes that stood out. But I think the story drew me in so much at times that I did not notice the music at all. 


Enjoyment: 8/10 

Overall 8/10

I think it was a great anime with a great ending worth waiting for. For those who like darker anime or some yaoi, this is definitely an anime for you. This is definitely an anime more for women since there are so many yaoi moments and fan service but the action scenes I think would definitely appeal to fans of action as well. This is an anime I would definitely recommend as Sebastien truly is "one hell of a butler" ;) and really made it worth watching.

Kuroshitsuji is definetly must see anime!! It has a well-constructed plot and great characters. The story is filled with unexpected turn-of-events, tear-jerking moments, as well as laugh-out-loud moments and of course of nice dose of action. The characters are all unique in their own ways and, most of them, you can't help but to love. Althought it is pointed towards a female audience, with bishonens and yaoi snippets, it can also be enjoyed by a male audience. The dark atmosphere, accompanied by exceptional artwork and music, will probably be enjoyed especially by fans of darker animes. But, overall, Kuroshitsuji is a great series that youshould not overlook! ^.^

After numerous requests from the worst fanboys, I decided to give a chance to this series because of the interesting plot and character's desing.
From this point of view the anime is well done, with a cast characterized and stylish but that, at least according to my personal point of view, errs in the evolution, especially for secondary elements, and makes it less convincing and addictive . Another major flaw worth mentioning  is the presence of too many unnecessary episodes also in the final parts of the plot, in which it would be right and lawful push a little 'more on the accelerator to enticethe viewer and immerse completely in the events, finishing for get bored and wonder why it was given so much space to this kind of episodes,even considering the nature of these anime,the black comedy. Closing the topic on episodes’ management, I want to further criticize the decision to exclude the narrative arcs that in the plot could do good, and then make room for boredom masterpieces like the one dedicated to the Indian Butler and Prince Soma, which excluding the culinary challenge vaguely reminiscent of Food Wars, it is useless and somewhat avoidable.


Speaking of the plot, however, we are facing  a well written story with a very original underlying idea, that every time brings our beloved characters to shed light on court’s mysteries and solve cases like real investigators. If this anime’s part captures the attention and leads to continuing the vision to find the culprit and the motive of the crime, the continual solving these misdeeds blocks the flow of the real plot, which leads to a villain’s presentation in the anime’s closing stages and a hasty unfolding of events, that does not help in the rating.


On the technical side, anyway, there are respectable animations with appreciable drawings, both for the author's obvious personality that shines through in every lineament, but also for the originality that nowadays is hard to find.


Honorable mention for the ending and the final episode itself, which concludes perfectly the first season of Kuroshitsuji, offering striking and exciting scenes that I liked a lot. In the general despair and chaos within London, we see Ciel increasingly determined to implement his revenge,even when all is lost and nothing remains, driven by hatred and frustration, the main themes of this anime. The Earl and the butler Sebastian’s final stages are also beautiful, that contributes to strengthen the bond of friendship between them, gaining in characterization and character development, and giving an unique touch of class with deep reflections and very significant scenes.


Finally, arguing on the setting, I cannot avoid showing me pleased and surprised with this Gothic style,that I love in all its gorges,and a realistic and commendable Victorian London’s scenario, really proving the main advantage of this anime. Continuing the discourse on the artistic side, this anime also affects for the care given in the soundtrack with a fantastic opening and, albeit with a first undertone ending, a really magnificent and full of atmosphere closing song (Lacrimosa),that can not be skipped.


Summing up, Kuroshitsuji is an anime that I would highly recommend to all of those who love black comedies and those who want to approach something that stands out from the crowd for its originality and personality, detectable in the character’s design and in the magnificent gothic environments that are the anime’s main dishes.

This was an incredible anime, it has a European vibe while maintaining a Japanese type vibe as well. It has been very well thought out. It may have an  overpowered character.However as you will see later on in the story, that doesn't effect the outcome. It has a very decent looking animation. As well as having amazing plot. If you are interested in a supernatural - mystery - comedy - drama type anime, then this is one you must try out. It  really is Brilliant!I liked the anime mainly because of the main characters. The main two are a perfect duo for eachother. The name Black Butler also fits the anime quite well once you've seen and looked at it.

First of all, I have zero idea what was going on with the plot of this anime. Don't get me wrong, the characters were great, but I feel like you'd have to read the manga to really get your money's worth on the storyline. 
Essentially, there were many differing bits of story throughout the entire season that didn't really fit together. I understand the overall point and meaning of the story, but it just wasn't executed all that well.
That being said, the characters in this anime are some of the best I've seen in this genre. However, their backgrounds weren't really touched on as muchas I would've liked them to be, and in fact, the parts of them we did see didn't make much sense in the grand scheme of the season. \n\n
Probably the one thing that was simultaneously the most confusing and most interesting about this anime was Ciel and Sebastian's relationship. It was very intriguing trying to figure out the depths of it--or rather, if there was any depth at all. \n\n
I'm hoping that the second season brings more clarity as to the point of Ciel's journey with Sebastian, beyond the obvious (Sebastian wanting to... you know, eat him). We'll see, I suppose.

First of all, you must know, this anime is completely different from the manga, like its two totally different stories. This must be one of the reasons why the storyline of this anime was all over the place. But let's judge this anime on its own, ignoring the fact it was mostly non-canon. For me, I felt confused at times while watching because I couldn't understand the storyline, like what exactly was the plot. The characters were so thinly portrait that you couldn't really relate or understand their motives. However, I must admit I liked the anime before I read the manga because I foundit entertaining even though I couldn't get on board with the storyline. And it seems the anime redeem itself with the movies, where the plot was similar to the manga. So if you want an anime to watch for fun, I'll give this a go.

Emo is the best word I can describe this show with.
Story: Alright so the story goes with the whole “I need my revenge” plot, except the once the deed is done our main character (Ciel), who made a pact with his butler Sebastian who is a demon, will have his soul taken by said butler. Honestly the show was nothing but sad and depressing moments.  If your into this kind of stuff then this is right for you.
Characters: 
 Ciel: I could not stand this little puk, I mean he is a prideful emo kid who the writers tried to give aheart change in the end but it just did not work.


 Sebastian: alright he a good butler and I won’t lie. He is a calm person who has skills but still does not add much to the story.


Everyone else: not memorable


P.S Season 2 is not worth watching since undid the ending of season 1.

Kuroshitsuji, as well called Black Butler, is an anime based on the manga "Kuroshitsuji" by Yana Toboso. It was directed by Toshiya Shinohara and produced by A-1 Pictures. The anime derives from the original story of the manga, but it was Yana Toboso who still created the story of the anime.
Summary:
"In Victorian-era Europe, a young boy loses everything he once held near and dear to a vicious plot. In his moment of death, he strikes a deal with a demon: his soul, in exchange for revenge. Ciel Phantomhive is now the head of the Phantomhive corporation, handling all business affairs as well as the undergroundwork for the Queen of England. His new partner is a demon butler, Sebastian Michaelis, whose powers as a butler is only surpassed by his strength as a demon.


The story follows the two along with their other servants, as they work to unravel the plot behind Ciel's parents' murder, and the horrendous tragedies that befell Ciel in the month directly after." (source : kissanime.com)


Story (10)


The story is a dark fantasy that mixes well mystery and humor. The dialogues are funny and well written. Sometimes here and there unexpected scenes but that doesn't make the anime less fun to watch.


Art (9)


Beautiful artwork in my opinion. This of course depends on each person but A-1 Pictures did a great job finding this anime his "own style". The clothing of the era is very well drawn despite it's surrealistic story. 


Sound (9)


The voice actors ar well chosen. Their voices suite really well with thei character and do a great job impressioning them.

As for the background music, it is in the style and I didn't get a feeling like "oh, this shouldn't be here". The openings and endings are also well chosen and some of them can be catchy.


Character (10)


Each character had their own characteristic (that makes them easy to remember). They don't really change throughout the story (even if sometimes you might get that impression) but it doesn't really matter for the plot. 


Enjoyement (10)


Like I stated before, it's mysterious and fun at the same time so yeah, believe you will laugh. The suspence is well build and when you think "oh this is solved" you get another question... So it isn't boring for sure, and very enjoyable. 


Overall (10)


I thought it was a very outstanding anime, surely one of my favorites. Good story, amazing characters, nice artstyle... 


So yeah, hope this was helpfull and picked your curiosity! ^^

I had this anime recommended to me several times before finally watching it and
