Story: This anime diverges from the manga, if you wanted just the manga's adaptation, stop watching this series after episode 13, then skip to Book of Circus. If you want the whole thing (which I recommend), watch this, then Kuroshitsuji II and then Book of Circus. The story in this was very well done, being a story that kept me thoroughly engaged throughout the entire binge- I mean, watching session. It never got too slow, but kept up a good level of action and believable, yet unpredictable twists and turns throughout. The9/10 is justified in my mind.


Art: The art in this anime is quite well done, smooth animation, coupled with a good drawing style, and consistency is a wonderful thing to have. 9/10 for art.


Sound: The soundtrack was pretty good for this anime, nice OP and ED, as well as some good OST in the background. 8/10 for sound.


Character: Grell is the single-most best thing I have ever experienced and with the best VA, Jun Fukuyama, he definitely had a wonderful time to shi-


Sorry, fangirled too hard again. Keeping a more composed review, I was glad to see a return of my favourite VA in a fun new character, that I greatly enjoyed and believed was a fun spot of comic relief every now and again. The main cast is also developed quite well, as mysteries surrounding the mysterious past are unfolded and you learn that everything is not as it seems or as you initially anticipated within the Earl of Phantomhive's mansion. I really like the voice cast for majority of the main characters and believe that this deserves it's 9/10 for characters.


Enjoyment: The enjoyment for me was a perfect 10/10. I found the pacing of the story was quite good, never getting too slow and always making me want to see more. I don't have too many bones to pick with this anime, from an enjoyment point of view.


Overall: I really enjoyed this anime and think that it ended quite perfectly, summing up everything with no loose ends, it is definitely something that I would recommend, but I do understand that it is not for everyone, and some view it as a primarily teen girl demographic, despite it's shounen tag. I would not like to throw my hat into the ring for that argument, but I will say that I can understand both sides' reasonings. Overall a good anime, 9/10.

Black Butler is one of my two favorite animated ! How to describe themselves busy so it is great (I have not read the manga, shame on me ^^) : in short, expect a senario so unexpected, graphics and awesome sound, crafted characters ... all in a murky england. Anyway, I'm not very good at faires paved but I assure you it is awesome and you should definitely read / watch.

The frustrating thing about creating an adaptation is that no matter how hard you try, you’re inevitably going to end up straying from the original source material.
You can use that phrase to start off reviews for the majority of anime on this site, because nearly every anime adaptation, no matter how faithful, has a few differentiations from the manga or light novel it’s based on.
However, once in a while, you get an anime that ends up drifting so far from its source that it eventually spins off into a completely new direction, to the point where the two hardly feel like the same story anymore.This is exactly what Black Butler is like. I’ve been a fan of the manga for quite some time before I decided to check out the anime. It was the creative use of the Victorian setting, dark themes, and colorful cast of characters that pulled me into the series as I read. Even though I knew that the anime and manga were different, I didn’t realize how different they actually were until I watched the anime.


The anime begins following the manga well enough. The first few episodes essentially cover the first few chapters of the manga. Our first arc, the Jack the Ripper Arc, is actually covered rather flawlessly. The feelings Yana Toboso wanted you to experience are perfectly translated into the anime. You develop a strong desire to find Jack the Ripper’s true identity. You laugh hysterically at Ciel wearing a dress. Your spine chills at the reveal of Grell Sutcliffe. Your heart breaks listening to the devastating backstory of Madame Red. You get a better understanding of Ciel’s character when the arc ends.


However, as the show progresses and new story arcs come and go the plot begins to fall apart. None of the other arcs really hold a candle to the Jack the Ripper Arc. The show tries to tie all the arcs together, but it does this in a completely unsatisfying way. For example, in one arc, they are supposed to investigate a weird church. They do that for about half an episode, then all of a sudden the main villain appears and the church is never brought up again.


Not even the other arc adapted from the manga, the Curry Contest Arc is particularly good. It feels very rushed, like they weren’t interested in adapting it, but needed to in order to introduce the characters Soma and Agni. It cuts some rather major events from the manga version. Worst of all, it does a poor job portraying the character Soma. The anime puts way too much emphasis on his spoiled bratty side. Of course, this is an aspect of his character in the manga, but it’s hardly the defining feature.


This is a rather major issue in the anime. The story arcs become less about developing the characters they’ve already introduced, and more about adding new characters and story elements in an attempt to make the show seem edgier. Because of this, there is a depressing lack of character development among the side characters. Most of them aren’t shown to the full potential they are capable of. I realize they can only adapt what was actually published at the time, but they could have at least talked to Yana Toboso to discuss what direction she was planning on taking with these characters.


The worst example of this is Grell Sutcliffe. I mentioned earlier how intimidating he was when he was first introduced in the Jack the Ripper Arc. After that arc though, pretty much every appearance he makes is a huge flop. Part of the reason for this is how frequently he appears. In the manga, Grell doesn’t appear after the Jack the Ripper Arc for over 10 volumes. In the anime, he appears all the freaking time and has absolutely no impact on the story at hand. He’s reduced to a perverted mess who lusts after Sebastian or whatever other man he happens to see. He only gets in the way, taking away precious time that could have been spent focusing on developing something else.


Pluto, the demon hound who doesn’t appear in the manga is another worthless character, except unlike Grell, he was never likable to begin with. His sole existence in this show is to provide fanservice to the yaoi fangirls, so they can squee with delight as he jumps onto Sebastian or Ciel while butt naked. He does nothing even slightly amusing in the showl, and the arc that introduces him is probably the weakest in the show.


You’d probably assume that from the scathing comments I make towards the story and characters that I really hate this anime. Actually, I don’t. In fact, the overall time I spent watching this anime was definitely an enjoyable one. Even though the anime doesn’t do a very good job adapting what was in the manga, it still has a “Black Butler” feel. Sure, the mood is completely different, but there are definitely some positive elements to it. So let’s talk about the good now.


First, there’s Ciel. Ciel is a great character, and the anime does a good job showing this. He’s not some stuck-up snobby kid, nor is he totally dependent on Sebastian, which a lot of people might think he is. He’s perfectly capable of defending himself. He’s cunning, manipulative, resourceful, and not afraid to get his hands dirty. But underneath, he really is a good person. He genuinely cares about all of his friends and servants and though he’s bossy, he’s not cruel. Ciel is someone who really does want to do the right thing; he just tries not to show it.


I’m not sure I can say Ciel really “develops” in the sense that he learns lessons and grows into a different person. Rather he “develops” in the sense that the events of the show reinforce who Ciel is as a character. The best example of this is near the end. Basically, when confronted with the opportunity to forget his past, Ciel says he can’t, and that he needs to hold onto his past because it is the hatred he has for those that killed his parents that have made him into the person he is. I found this to be a pretty valid reason.


Sebastian was also a character I enjoyed. He’s mysterious, and the dynamic between him and Ciel is explored fascinatingly. While he’s obedient to Ciel, you can tell that he’s not particularly loyal. You’re never sure what’s going on through his mind, but the show doesn’t want you to know. Though he is perfect at nearly everything he does, he doesn’t seem like an idealized Mary Sue. And the sarcastic and somewhat passive-aggressive way he talks is quite amusing. Though he doesn’t have much depth, he’s very likable and easy to root for.


I liked the character of Angela, a character exclusive to the anime. I’m not really sure why though, because she’s not particularly deep nor is she very interesting. Her character is never explored, nor are her motivations explained at all. Why is she doing what she’s doing? What is she trying to accomplish? It seems like acts more for the hell of it rather than any real reason. I think I like her more for what she is, rather than who she is. Overall though, she’s an interesting addition, and I would love seeing her in the manga, granted with some more depth.


The visuals in this anime are incredibly impressive. The setting portrayed in the manga is animated spectacularly well. The backgrounds are detailed beautifully, and the animation flows smoothly. The dim lighting and gothic character designs helps contribute to the mood of the anime immensely. It does a fantastic job depicting a somber atmosphere. What particularly impresses me is how much effort they put into the historical accuracy. Obviously, they took some creative license, but you can tell that they did as much research as they possibly could in order to portray London as best as they could. The only thing I didn’t like was how obvious it was that they used CG for the horse drawn carriages. They stand out too much. I realize that it was probably cheaper, but come on; horses can’t be that hard to animate in 2D.


The music is very fitting for this time period. Not all of it is typical classical baroque-esque music like you’d expect, though there is a good share of it. Even the more modern music in incorporates into the background fits the scene well. The OP is a great song. It’s catchy and it relates to the show well. The first ED is also a great song and the video for it is fantastic, though I’m not sure how well it fits the anime. Meanwhile, the second ED, sung by Kalafina, is beautiful. It’s slow paced, mysterious, and it relates to the show lot better, especially as the show gets darker.


The voice acting for the English dub is fantastic. I’ve heard a lot of criticism that they don’t properly use the correct accents, but as an American, I never noticed. Even if they didn’t bother to use accents at all, you could tell that the voice actors put a lot of effort into this dub, and they really enjoyed it in the process. Brina Palencia was a perfect choice for Ciel. Her voice is flat, but not emotionless; exactly the kind of character Ciel is. Meanwhile, J. Michael Tatum does a fantastic job as Sebastian. His seductive voice captures the essence of the character excellently, and his tone adds a lot to the character’s witty humor.


It’s difficult to pin my overall thoughts on Black Butler, because I don’t hate it, but I don’t think I like it all that much either. While the visuals and sound is nice and Ciel and Sebastian are handled exceptionally well, the rest of the cast and story are heavily downplayed and do not do the manga justice. It’s not necessarily the fact that it doesn’t directly adapt the manga that hurts it. It’s the fact that what they replaced it with just isn’t that good.

Kuroshitsuji was a wonderful anime, laced with bitter revenge and heart ache. It contains the most complex and mysterious characters you will ever come across, and with a beautiful musical soundtrack, this will not disappoint. Even though the characters were victorian, they were easy to understand but not at all modern, which proved the effort put into this anime was emmense.
*spoilers*
Story: 10-
Ciel Phantomhive, 12 year old earl, is possibly one of the strangest and strongest characters you will ever come across. His adventures are far from heroic, and the storyline of Kuroshitsuji had so many twists that I was honestly surprised at times. From hypocriticalangels obssessed with "purity", to the ghosts of the princes of the tower and Grelle the grim reaper, there wasn't a moment in this story that didn't leave me happy, sad, or intruiged. The action was well balanced, the peaceful moments not boring at all, and the upsetting scenes timed perfectly. If your looking for twists, secrets, lies and betrayal, this anime is definitely for you.


Sound: 9-


I wasn't fond of the opening theme at first, but it grew on me. There were many scenes and episodes in the anime that contained beautiful music, and it was honestly surprising how well timed they were. I downloaded the soundtrack and thought that was also gorgeous.


Character: 10-


Ciel Phantomhive, not your typical spoilt preteen. Despite his pessimist attitude, he has a past clouded with mystery, and his secrets are more complex than you can ever imagine. He is bound to a demon butler who's trying to eat his soul, but he plays this to his advantage, seeking revenge on those who hurt him. Ciel is fun to watch but I sometimes wish he would see how bright the world really was.


Sebastian Michealis, not your typical butler. His favourite quote is "I am simply one HELL of a butler.", which seems to be his favourite pun. He can go from evil to playful in a split second, and often seems to be protective of his master. However, don't be fooled, he is a demon, and seems to have no heart at all. He seriously just wants to devour Ciels soul. Thus you could call him a villian, yet a lot of the time you could call him the hero, protecting Ciel no matter what, even if it causes his own pain and anguish. A truly amazing character.


The servants don't seem to be sad or burdened servants at all. They are enthusiastic and all have their pasts that made them stronger and better, and are no longer hurt or afraid. They do there duty well and are very enjoyable characters to watch, especially Tanaka and Finny, who are my personal favourites.


Grelle, the somewhat disturbed grim reaper, who finds fun in everything. I have been unable to decide whether I like him or not, however he makes me laugh, and that's something. Grelle is seriously one hell of a character.


Other characters are also complex and amazing! The villians are not bigots, their opinions can almost be justified and their minds seemed to be wired in the perfect way to make them brutal and not easy to watch. That's a good thing. Characters like Lizzy and Madame Red almost brung me to tears, and the undertakers character is also hilarious.


To sum this character review up, all the characters in this series were, to put it frankly, awesome. Their words and history never cease to surprise me. 


Overall: 9-


Throught this show I was shocked, scared, happy, sad, and suspicious. The art was sweet, the music was lush, the characters were intruiging and I enjoyed it emmensely. I'm serious that if you watch Kuroshitsuji, you will not find a fantasy world, but more like a harsh reality full of messages and secret morals.


This anime was amazing and I hope to find more like it ^^

As I began to watch this anime, I didn't have high hopes nor was I completely impressed with the first few episodes. But perseverance paid off, and I found the story to be quirky and enjoyable. 
When I thought they would go down a conventional plotline/reaction, there would suddenly be a twist that would make me laugh. Overall, this anime was kept very fresh throughout the episodes. There are some obvious filler episodes that became slightly boring, but the humor was enough to keep me from looking away. The characters, while cliche in their actions, have a sort of warm and fresh feel in suchthat you forgive them immediately if they do something predictable.


The artistry is beautiful. The background and settings can sometimes be breathtaking and the attention to detail is impressive.


After finishing, I started on the second series, which could also be a bit of an OAV as well, Kuroshitsuji II. The first episode threw me off a bit as I thought that the main characters from the first series wouldn't be in it, but that wasn't so and the new plot line really had me hooked, the ending episodes are really worth it. 


I would say I think I enjoyed Kuroshitsuji II more than the first one, but I wouldn't have the attachment to the main characters I did if I hadn't watched the first series before. Overall, I recommend both to the age groups of about 12 to 35. It's kiddy enough that younger people will enjoy it, but witty and fast paced enough for the older generation looking for something new.

I'm not one for black people or butlers, but I found this show fantastic. Everything about it is so delicious and just saturated with really aggressive bass-lines. Takes place in London during the Victorian period, a time we all remember fondly and wish we could go back to. The main character is Ciel Phantomhive, with his parents killed he is now the head of his noble family, he is out to kill the people that killed his parents and  beat him naked with a cane or something. To accomplish his goal he makes a deal with a demon, Sebastian, who can do a bunchof demon shit and becomes his trusted butler that carries out his wishes. Ciel and Sebastian are extremely likeable and you want them to succeed, I won't go over the rest of the characters but the villains are really cool and jack the ripper is in it, though probably not what you'll be expecting. There is a really cool blend of comedy and action, you really won't know what to expect next as it is always switching from being funny to dead serious. This show's soundtrack is quite good and the art is very easy on the eyes, unlike cancer. You will like watching this show, I know you will. Because you are probably a retarded fourteen year old and have horrible taste, either that or you're a woman and have horrible taste in everything, stupid women. I didn't mean the last part, many women have great taste in entertainment among other things, I only put it in to get your respect.

Kuroshitsuji or Black Butler whatever you want to call it is amazing and I recommend you go watch it right now!
I started watching it without reading anything about it, so I was basically clueless. But I was just lost in it as soon as I watched the first episode.
The story was amazing, a young boy and his demon butler, as soon as they make their contract the demon must serve his master and be there for him always, but when the time comes the demon shall devour his master's soul. (Sounds a bit like Death Note when you write it down.)
I loved all the arcsespecially the Jack The Ripper one. I loved the kind of twist there was with who was involved and how it all went down. I also loved the arc with the young girls being kidnapped and transformed into dolls. And pretty much all of the arcs. I wasn't a big lover of the hell hound arc but that was because I couldn't stand the scene with the dog being hurt by the evil dogs. (But that's just how I am with all scenes like that) 


The art was interesting, the characters all looked amazing, especially Sebastian and Ciel. Finny was adorable and I loved how Mey Rin's glasses covered up her true beauty. When they showed her past at the start of an episode I didn't even know it was her. She looked so different. 

Grell had the creepy look Grell needed (I'm still confused on Grell's gender) The backgrounds looked really nice all the time. The ending animation for the first ending song was cute and fun. The opening animation showed the creepy side to the anime, but it was really cool.


The sound was really good. The background music was good and the voices were all really good too. I liked all the British accents too. I really liked the opening song and the first ending song.


The characters were amazing. Each one stood out and they weren't easily forgotten. I loved Sebastian and Ciel. Elizabeth annoyed me but I think she's supposed to be annoying. The Phantomhive servants were all unique in their own crazy way and the villains were really enjoyable. 


Overall Kuroshitsuji is really enjoyable and I highly recommend it. It's not what I was expecting, it was better and I personally can't get enough of the quote "I'm simply one hell of a butler."

Black Butler Season 1 gets a 10 for being a great series. It is a Gothic / Occult Action and Black Comedy. The story is about a young noble who makes a Faustian deal with a Demoinc Butler who serves and protects him in Victorian Europe.The main character Ciel suffers tragedy of losing his parents as a child , since this , he is seeking revenge. The series goes through many supernatural adventures. 
For those who like Holmisian mysteries , history ,traveling, folklore and mythology , you will enjoy this anime. It has some stereotypical humor, such as one of the servants having a monocle, which is a typical look for a gentleman in Victorian England. There is a lot of action , and fighting , as well as solving mysteries. You will encounter creatures , from Fallen Angels to Demons ,to Hellhounds , to ghosts and of course Grim Reapers. You will also encounter various historical references in this period, such as the Great Exhibition in London , and Queen Victoria herself . You will also encounter references to historical mysteries such as Jack the Ripper and the murder of Richard Duke of York , and Edward IV in the Tower of London. Overall these facts alone set the stage for what I believe to be one of the best anime in the mystery of genre to date.

I have just started watching anime for about a year or so, and finished Kuroshitsuji quite a while back. This is by far my favourite anime, I felt like I knew the characters so well and the morals of the show were very fresh to me. 
I started off watching shoujo romance anime, and then started watching darker themed animes like this one. I love the underlying storyline and backstory of the characters and how they came about to how they are now. Whilst watching it, I became impressed by the art of the anime, the details that are put into the buildings, to theclothes are just amazing. \n\n
The story plot for me was extremely fresh, which is probably the reason why its my favourite anime. Like I said before, I felt so connected to the characters, thats probably why it stand out from other animes like SNK and Mirai Nikki - don't get me wrong, these 2 animes are excellent as well, its just a personal preference.

well I have always wanted to watch Black butler but i didn't have any time to, but I finally got my chance ,at first everything seemed normal and nothing much was unleashed which i thought was normal of course but all the praises and compliments i've heard about how amazing this anime is, made me rethink about the beginning being so humble, i prejudged it after the episode 9 ,, and i thought it wasn't that much of an anime and it didn't reach my expectations, but as i continued ,my review began to change gradually , It finally reached my expectations after the finalepisode ! everything afterward went just perfectly as it should've been for it in order to have my liking, i surprisingly and strangely changed my point of view about this anime , anyways the biggest flaw is still not having a storyline ,,.. unfortunately it lacked the goal of the anime, every episode has a different meaning and a total different goal except some few ,.. i thought it would be even greater if it had a specific manner to liven up the watcher and rise the excitement for another degree further, specially those who tend to get bored when there is no goal existing in the anime and every episode has a different line even if not totally or entirely different , it's pretty much the same, I'd give it the highest rating if it was just a little better ,but i think that is enough for a great anime .. the second season remains unwatched ,, soon i might completely change my mind about this anime but first the second season must be seen, there are some few other things which i didn't like about this anime but since i can't say any without putting some spoilers on the front i didn't say or utter any .. maybe a hint,, .. even though the flaw of the story for me is that it didn't match up to a really specific storyline, even the little goal that existed in the story wasn't much .. i usually tend to hate those animes that ignore the supporting character all the time, and try to give them some role if they want them to die so they'd be like kind of meaningful to the anime, also the stories that are just put to fill the emptiness the Studio tends sometime to feel in the anime, some meaningless things i don't appreciate but I'm surely not the kind of a person who likes to criticize any anime unless i really liked it and wanted it to have been even better, Like this one I'm reviewing, I don't care if you find my review unhelpful by the way :P

I have mixed feelings about this series.  It's VERY dark (child sacrifice, selling souls to demons, horrific murders, evil angels), up the very end.  Particularly after the series deviates from the manga storyline.  However, there are many exciting parts, interesting characters,  and gorgeous animation.  It made me feel pretty weird and messed up inside once it was over.  So consider yourself cautioned.

I only picked this up after seeing the awesome art on some posters at conventions. And the art does not fail it. It's eye candy 100%. 
However it is more than just art. 
The characters are quite interesting, when you get to know them, which might as well take as much as the entire show. 
I think then evolution of the characters to similar to that of the Gundam 00 ones. Takes you an  entire season to find out how fucked up they are and the entire second season to warm up to them. Sadly enough, I think the second season of Kuroshitsuji hasa different line up. 


The story is pretty straight forward. Regardless of the usual amount of twists and turns, there are no jaw dropping revelations. 


The sound was, well nothing spectacular. I complimented the series without standing out, which is a good thing. 


I did drop this six episodes into it. One of the reviews I read compared it to Hellsing  so my expectations were a bit misplaced. As such, the happy end theme and the "happy" antics which composed the first half of the series were a bit of let down. But the visuals compelled me to rewatch it, taking it for what it was, and this time around I did enjoy it. 

I would have loved this series to push it a bit. A bit more fighting, a bit more raunchiness, a bit more gritty. They make the jack the ripper crimes and opium dens look totally bland. 

Still looking forward to season 2, will pro'lly pick up the manga as well and the rewatch it. 

So yeah, watch it. It is a decent series.

Kuroshitsuji was an outstanding piece of work.  
The story kept me wanting to watch it through to the end, even when I came upon an obvious filler episode, I still wanted to watch because I enjoyed it so much.  The animation was very good, and the music was some of the best I've heard in a long while.
I cannot wait for season 2 to come out ^^  Hopefully it will be as good as or better than the first.

Would you sell your soul to a demon if you could to?Kuroshitsuji is one of the few animes that will show you that.Besides the story, kuroshitsuji gives the word (demon) a new meaning:black butlers with unbelievable abilities.However,along the story you usually face some ordinary scenes like  parties and tea/cake time.Somehow, some of these elements were important to build a beautiful scenario and characterize some characters.Ones will say kuroshitsuji is just an ordinary anime, others will say that it is a masterpiece.However, I disagree with both opinions.Why?Here are the reasons:
Story/Art: 8/10-Kuroshitsuji has some interesting parts and a lot of action in its story,but i haveto say the ordinary scenes I watched really teased me and I almost dropped it.In the other hand the history aspect inserted in the anime gave it  great opportunities to explore events like:Jack the ripper,Queen victoria,The opium war..Besides,kuroshi also has some funny characters and parts.The art is very good, but not marvelous.If you like European scenes like me, Im sure you will enjoy/enjoyed it a lot.


Sound-8/10:There are good songs in the anime.Because of it, action scenes were more exciting.If you are searching for a spectacular soundtrack and marvelous effects kuroshitsuji is not the anime though.


Characters/Enjoyment/overall-9/10: There are some interesting and peculiar characters in this anime.I have to admit that i liked a lot almost all of them.Greil has an abnormal ability to make you laugh.Sebastian  has a mysterious air.He is also very charismatic.Ciel has a strong personality.The employees are always contributing to make the story more interesting.Then you ask me...why did you give it 9?Although I think art and sound are very important..I m sure enjoyment/story/characters are the most important points in an anime serie and beacuse of it and other reasons Kuroshitsuji is a great anime.

I don’t even know where to begin with this one. This review is painful even for me to write, because I would have to think about the show whenever I have to type. This show is probably one of the most famous and most talked about shows in anime history; probably because of the character design and the relationships of the different characters in the show (I don’t even want talk about that one, as much as possible, seriously now.) But it’s mostly because, no matter where you go, BLack ButLer (or Kuroshitsuji, for the people that know it better like that) is present ineverything and everywhere, both during the past and in the present .In the TV, in the web, in the magazines, BLack ButLer is always there, especially during the day it was being aired for the first time, although I have to admit that the hype died down during the past few years after it was first aired, but it sure as hell didn’t left the spotlight without making a scar big enough to be seen by the different aspiring mangaka and anime makers that showcase the genre that started it all, BL (although it’s not as rough as the other BL shows out there, and you can’t really specifically call BLack ButLer BL because it’s more of pseudo BL, it still feels appropriate if we did associate it with BL, for obvious reasons of course [at least they were sane enough to make it look subtle, yet provocative]). I am at least impressed that they serialized this show ‘passionately’, with evil smiles, and with an even more evil glare on the money, knowing that fans will bite it to the bone. (fan-girls to be specific. I’ll be damned if I find a single fan-boy in this show, if there was, you have every right to throw me in hell for this statement. Just don’t let Sebastian eat my soul. HAH! [I think I’m going to be sick just making that joke...])


But enough of that for now, let us move towards the actual review. BLack ButLer, BB for short, “is story about a boy that had lost everything he once held dear to him because of a conspiracy that grudges his family name. In his dying breath, he swore an oath to a demon. It will save his life and grant the boy’s wish of vengeance to the conspirators, but in return, the boy’s soul will be devoured by the demon when the wish is fulfilled.” From the moment the quotation mark ended, you probably think that ‘you know where this is going’. I am here to make it double sure that it will end like how you think it will (and it is not going to be a happy ending, although I won’t spoil what will happen). With that said, that pretty much summarizes the main plot itself, of course the small flash backs into the main character’s past is always a good motivation to anyone that will watch this show for the plot, but it will probably be not good enough to drive most of the viewers, unless you have the will power of Ghandi, you’re after the bishounen characters and the pseudo BL relationships to begin with, or you went for the bishounen characters and the pseudo BL relationships half-way of the show because the fillers just over-burdened you (I hope Ghandi lends his support to you, or else, you’re f***ed). Speaking of fillers, be prepared to enjoy bishounen, pseudo BL fillers with this one, because, at least, 70% of the whole show (season 2 not included) is filler-hell. (THERE I SAID IT. IF YOU DON’T LIKE FILLERS THEN STOP READING THIS REVIEW AND NEVER WATCH THIS SHOW, EVER! LEAVE WHILE YOU STILL CAN! [At least that’s settled...] You’re still here? *sigh*). Other than that, there’s pretty much nothing to say here, other than his, sort of peaceful, everyday life being a rich noble English kid, with his demon butler that can do anything, his quirky servant trio (can’t really call the old man a servant, he’s not doing any house work), and his occasional visitors that pesters him in his daily work-life to do various activities that will mostly annoy him to death and have no relevant meaning to the plot whatsoever, although some of the small stuff does have a connection with the plot, it’s not going to be anything major that you will remember it happening after finishing the whole show (considering that you did actually finished it). 


I will not talk about character design for this show because talking about it here would spoil the surprise installed for you when you watch the show, giving potential spoilers to people that are after the bishounen characters and pseudo BL relationships (also, character design in this one is too painful to describe in my point of view, given that I too have my fare share of bias, forgive the incompetence). Even though I said that, I will at least talk about character development. The funny thing about character development in this show is that there is barely any development. Little boy blue (balls) Ciel Phantomhive’s personality never did change since the start of the show, and his BLack ButLer, Sebastian Michaelis, never did reveal a whole lot of personal stuff about himself, other than his constant bragging of how much of a godly-ass butler he is. The only solid development that happened in the story was with the people that got into Ciel’s way. They all started out to be normal persons with different motives and interests, then all of a sudden, they became lunatics bent on killing Ciel due to personal issues. The main antagonist (which was not revealed until half of the entire show) did the most character development in the period of the show, showing him/herself that he/she’s the type that believes that ‘everything can be saved from hatred’ and that ‘ends must justifies it’s means’ then went power-hungry and started killing people for personal gain. The reason why I did say there was no character development for Ciel was because, when the story started, he had a back-story that revealed what he have been through. I can’t really say that it was legit character development because that said event happened before the show started, and only appears as flash-backs, so it technically doesn’t count as a development. Ciel, to be frank, started out to be a fully developed character already, which is not bad, but it still gave the impression that character development was flat with the main character.


Back to BL, I mean BB. Personally, there are at least two things that I liked about the anime in general, the setting, and the opening and ending themes. I like how the story was put into the 1800’s British Empire theme, with their snazzy buildings, inhumane interior house-hold designs, fashion sense (I’m a bit reluctant to blurt that out, but it’s still true anyway), and sleazy accents. But the opening and the ending theme (the second ending, to be exact) is hands-down, one of the best things I have heard in forever, since I started watching anime. I give credit to the two bands that did the OP and the ED of that show (even though I don’t know their band names), they are awesome. If you don’t know what I mean, then stop skipping the OP and the ED all the time, and start listening to it.


And that concludes another review. If you ask me if I enjoyed watching the show, instinctively, I’ll tell you I did not because, I’ll be honest with everyone, I detest anything and everything that has a direct correlation with bishounen, BL, yaoi types, pseudo or not. Mainly due to a trauma I had to suffer after watching that one show that everybody keeps trapping in the internet that goes by the acronym BnP. Even now that show gives chill down the spine, enough to paralyze anyone in fear. And without further ado, I will now conclude the BL, I mean BB, review. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m now going to be busy writing those other stuff I’m going to finish. For you see, I am simply one hell of a writer, heh. (Tightens noose)

(This is my review on Black Butler (Kuroshitsuji) from my website)
This review is on the anime and NOT the manga, the series was the anime’s own adaptation and did not feature in the manga.
I will also be doing a review on Kuroshitsuji (Black Butler): Book of Circus at a later date.
*CONTAINS SPOILERS*
Date released: Japan – October 2008 (America/England – January 2011)
Breakdown:
Black butler is a show about a young boy called Ciel, who sells his soul to a demon named Sebastian so that he can exact his revenge for his family’s death, also successfully lead their confectionary and toy company called Funtom. The demon that Cielmakes the contract with takes the form of his butler and is in the image of his father, he is very loyal to Ciel and is required to protect, serve and arrive whenever he is summoned by his master Ciel.


My opinion on Black Butler:


Let me start by saying, Black Butler is one of my all-time favourite animes! I really think it is such a well-written series.


The theme of the anime is that a young boy called Ciel makes a deal with a demon called Sebastian. After Ciel’s parents died he was taken to be sold as a child slave and one day in captivity as he was being tortured, he cried out of desperation that he had given up on god and this is when he met Sebastian whom he now has a deal with to avenge his parents death.


Driven by sheer anger, revenge, hatred and hurt Ciel agreed to make a contract with Sebastian but the stipulation of this contract is that Sebastian gets to devour Ciel’s soul once it has been fulfilled. The theme of revenge and redemption are well put together and the story lines are very well crafted though it isn’t filled with non-stop action.


Black Butler certainly has it’s share of dark and supernatural battle scenes as well as witty, funny battle scenes, there is also quite a bit of dark humour out through the series, but it is really balanced out by its traditional anime comedy along with this it also has mystery, drama and romance which is carried out very well.


Every character is complex and the variety in personality is something I really enjoy, getting to know each character is a nice experience of watching this anime.


One big thing I loved about this anime is that there are certain points that make you want to laugh, cry and get angry at Sebastian and Ciel for the things they do but one part of the anime that always stays the same are the characters.


The characters Finny, Mey-Rin, Bard and Lizzy which are Ciel’s servants, always keep the comedic side to it and they have their own stories to tell.


Throughout the story we see many parts of Ciel, his many roles include, being Queen Victoria’s watchdog, running Britains underworld, avenging his parents death and with his “One hell of a butler” at hand, they both battle everything from drug runners and serial killers to demon hounds, angels, ghosts and other demons.


The only thing I can point out that is somewhat off-putting is the fake British accents, but I understand that not everyone can put on a good accent and after the first few episodes or so I found it funnier rather than an annoyance.


Scene from Episode 16

Scene from Episode 16


In the end, it doesn’t quite turn out as expected and I did like the ending, I have seen a lot of fans complain about how it ended but me personally I didn’t think it was so bad, I rather enjoyed that Ciel didn’t die and Sebastian ended up being his butler for the rest of eternity because he made a promise to Ciel that he would be his butler until the end. I won’t say how but Ciel ended up sharing his body with someone else who made a deal and the deal was that Ciel will turn into a demon when he gets his own body back.


Sebastian tried to kill Ciel so that he could have his soul but by the time he tries to do this, he is too late and Ciel is already a demon so now, for the rest of eternity Sebastian is Ciel’s butler.


It truly ends by Ciel and Sebastian leaving the house to the servants, they head to a field and it is then explained what happened and why Ciel is still alive and why Sebastian is still with him.


Rating – 8 / 10


Conclusion


Overall I personally found Black butler to be a fantastic anime, I really enjoyed it and it will always be up there with my favourites. The balance between dark and supernatural with traditional anime comedy really caught my attention and the storylines had me hooked! I would recommend this anime 100%.


I know that Kuroshitsuji (Black Butler): Book of Circus is a the new season of the anime, going back to the storyline that is in the manga so it is not considered a continuation of the previous seasons as it goes back to Noah’s arc Circus, but I would personally like to see another season which is a continuation of demon Ciel continuing with seeking revenge and possibly achieving this goal he has set out for himself as it would be interesting to see how Ciel’s personality has changed, what strengths he has now and just how differently he would carry out his tasks.


I guess that they want to stick to the manga storyline now so I do have high hopes for anything else they decide to release after Book of Circus! I’m excited to see what they have in store for Black Butler.


* I DID NOT watch the extra’s that have been released for Black Butler I just watched the main series so I’m unsure if they have done some spin off episodes where they have continued with demon Ciel’s story, as I prefer to wait until a series is completely finished before I watch the extras. I will definitely check them out and if there is a continuation, I will edit this post and put my thoughts on it *


If your opinion of this differs from mine, or you would just like to add anything then please feel free to let me know.

An amazing anime! So much darkness and the anime focuses on the story line aswell as the dark drawings which I found made the anime more enjoyable. A must watch if you enjoy darker anime like 'Hell girl' or an anime like 'Boku x inu ss'.
I would personally watch this anime 6 or more times over. I cannot get enough of this anime.
Only disappointing aspect is the fact that they need to make more episodes.

"I'm afraid when something is truly lost, one can never get it back again." A very mature thing for a 13-year-old earl to say. Today I'll be reviewing Kuroshitsuji also known as Black Butler.  I will break down everything in my review based on the divisions provided by MAL.
Story (7/10)
The story has aroused mixed feelings in me. I would say that the episodes were linked well to produce a continuous story, but throughout the whole series, it has been peppered with canon that was not quite relevant. But, in retrospect, these canons have served their purpose to develop the characters. Elizabeth did not, however,developed much of a character in the anime as shown in the manga.  The anime only followed the manga until the 15th episode and broke off after that to follow its own separate route. The originality of the story after the 15th episode was amazing and has managed to surprise me at a number of times.  The story grew more intense as it neared its end, drawing out the deeper, darker themes that have been concealed by lighter moods earlier on in the anime. The latter was done quite well as it manages to have viewers forget that the actual theme of the anime was darker than expected and leave them to crash land when the deceptive veil is lifted. The ending was quite satisfying and left open. How it all ended was simple and undramatic, which gave off a gloomy atmosphere, but with a sense of relief and letting go in it. 

Overall, I think the story was good.


Art (7/10)

Produced in 2009, the art style of the anime may seem a little old schooled, with less shading, beautiful lighting and lacking in depth. But it seems to fit the anime, seeing that it was set in the Victorian era, technology was barely existing yet. This might not be of relevance to the anime, but I think it's a legit point. The art style also portrays the dreary atmosphere of England, so it's quite fitting. The art style of the characters looks rough compared to recent anime, but it's not a flaw that has bothered me much. Plus, it has improved in all its more recent adaptations.


Sounds (6/10)

Sounds play a very big part in making or breaking an anime. The sounds in Kuroshitsuji are not as impressive and memorable as other anime such as K-Project but it has managed to bring out the essence of the anime. Korushitsuji has a mix of despondent sound tracks and happy-go-lucky ones that fit the moods, but none will stay with you long after you watch the anime. "Si deus me relinquit" was the only one that stuck to my mind. The opening and ending though are a different story.  The opening remained the same throughout the whole series, but has never bored me at the slightest. Ending #1 was cheerful and quirky with a "cinematic strip"of chibi Phantomhive household characters and has never failed to amuse and entertain. Ending #2, however, took on a darker twist, reflecting on the darkness of the anime. 


Character (7/10)

There is an abundance of characters in this anime, with different levels of development. There were characters who were generic and those who had unique personality. Some only had the purpose of lightening the atmosphere the way I see it. Most of the characters developed well in the anime, though some seem to have remained stagnant throughout. The reaction of the characters in certain situations were exaggerated, but it is partially comedy, so no faults there. The expressions were done right, portraying the characters' emotions well. The antagonist in the anime had motivations, but seem to be lacking in background. Why is the villain set on committing his heinous acts? We know why, but where is he coming from? What happened in the past that motivated him to do so? It can be said differently with the protagonist, Ciel Phantomhive. By asking the questions above, we know that he has background and motivation. I don't have a particular dislike for any characters, but I would forever remember Ciel Phantomhive. Though only in his (early) teen years, the protagonist has already lost much, forcing him to grow up and face the real world at a far too early age. The fact that he hasn't keeled over and has taken matters in his own hands led me to respect and look up to him. Although he has the help of a near invincible demon butler, he has remained strong and persistent. Those are qualities I aspire to have in my life. So, there is no surprise that I would remember him. 


Enjoyment (9/10) 

In terms of enjoyment, I basically had a great time watching this anime. The ability of the staff to create a light atmosphere that disguised the dark theme of this anime is amazing. I enjoyed the comedic moments and felt sadness when the plot took a darker turn. The comedy in the anime helped intensify the the feelings I felt when the series took on a serious vibe. I think this is a good anime; an anime that can drag you down so deep and lets you sympathize with the characters, but still give you some good laughs. Some will enjoy it, but others might not, because it left the manga entirely after the 15th episode. I would definitely rewatch it. It adds to my enjoyment and allows me to learn something new about the characters that I have missed. Kuroshitsuji has made it to my favourite anime list next to Attack on Titan.  


Overall, I highly enjoyed the anime and would recommand it to any anime lover or my friends. I think it's something that I can talk about passionately and it allows my mind to think about the dark themes explored in this anime. If you are interested in history, Black Butler offers tidbits of Victorian England history that will prompt the curious mind to do a little research. Kuroshitsuji is one of the 2 anime that has managed to make me cry and I believe that speaks a lot by itself. 

That's all I have for today. Thanks for reading!

Despite the first impression you may have (Specially Men);  Kuroshitsuji definitely is a very good anime, why? It has a complex and well elaborated plot, a great art, a very good character development and is very very entertaining.
Well... Where Should I Begin... The first time i heard of this anime, i said: "It's sounds like it's a good story" then i saw a picture and it was like: "What Kind Of Yaoi Is this? Definitely not my type of anime", The time passed and a friend of mine told me "Have you seen Kuroshitsuji, i'm sure you'll enjoy it, it's not what you think".And i give it a chance, and you know what: It's a Great Anime.


STORY: 9

Well you have already read the synopsis, A death then a deal with a demon then revenge... Sounds great, now the point is: The plot is large enough to have 24 episodes? Of course, it is well developed, no repetitive and it has no fillers. Despite it's a dark story it has very funny moments, just as the serious and mysterious situations, and they are completely balanced and don't interfere between them. And if you like English Culture, definitely you'll love this.


ART: 8

The drawings are great in every aspect, good use of the light, well animated, very detailed, but i've never liked chibi-stuff in a "serious" anime. Besides that, all great.


SOUND: 9

The music is awesome, it fits perfectly with the plot and the scenes. The Intro is a memorable one, the first outro goes well with the begining of the story (funny and relaxed) the second is great for the ending of the story (Very melancholic).


CHARACTERS: 9

Of course the main characters have been designed very well in every aspect, and are developed constantly and fine through the whole animation. But the secondary characters are not left behind, every one (or the great part of them) is well developed, so if you like psycological thrillers, you'll be very interested in this one.


OVERALL: 9

The story is good, the music, the art and everything else is good. So, It makes it a good/great anime, but now, Is it Enjoyable? YES, If you like thrillers, history, ocultism, Mystery, tragedy and comedy... YOU'LL LOVE THIS!

A common bit of wisom is that the journey is more important than the destination. 
With Black Butler, you can have it both ways.
We find out early on how it is most likely to end, and by episode 24, we get the expected payoff, but not before we're treated to one heckuva ride to get there.
The ending, while bittersweet and melancholy, is wholly expected; this did NOT spoil the series for me, as I was interested in the "artistry" the storyteller invested in this tale, start-to-finish, and some of the more annoying aspects early on (why I gave it only a seven for enjoyment becameclearer as the series progressed towards its conclusion.\n\n
Don't ask me about what happens after episode 24; for me, the series ended there.

Honestly my biggest mistake was reading the manga and then watching the anime. The manga has a fantastic story line that keeps you on edge and the detail and quality of the art is something to be envied. 
However, in comparison to the manga, to be quite frank, the anime is lacking. For some reason, the company decided to go on a completely different track than the manga, so about 90% of the anime isn't even canon. What a horrible mistake that was. For first time viewers who know nothing of the Kuroshitsuji world, the story line is confusing at best, and you receive anexplanation after half of the anime is already over, and even then things are unclear. Honestly the addition of extra characters and story plot annoyed me, and I found it irrelevant and just plain stupid. The ending is also extremely unsatisfying and doesn't even really make any sense in hind sight...


That aside, Yana Toboso worked on this anime as well, and if you've seen and/or read the manga you'll notice her additions right away. The art is high quality and detailed, and all of Ciel's outfits are different! T


The show is a good balance of action and humor, and you'll instantly fall in love with multiple characters as you learn more about them. 


I gave this anime an overall 9 despite the non canon plot. Although, perhaps I'm a bit biased after reading the manga...

Ahhh, where to start with this anime...
Story: 9/10
Alright, so the story is already written up there, so I really don't have to tell it over again. I loved this anime, mainly because it really didn't stick to one individual plot throughout the whole series. It has little plots in between as well. I also love how the actual story takes place in London, and the people there with the clothes and everything actually looked like it took place in the 1800's. Also, I love the fact that Sebastian is really sincere to his master, and never breaks the contract. I love how they added actualevents that happen in history as well. For example, the fair would always happen when the Thames river would turn to ice.


Art: 10/10!


I REALLY loved the art in this anime. The clothing that Ciel, Lady Elizabeth, and the background people wear actually look really decent to the fashion wear in the 1800's. I love how the creators used the characters as mannequins to show off the fashion wear of that time. I also mainly loved this anime based on the clothing and art.


Sound: 8/10


Alright, so I really don't judge an anime based on sound, but since I want to get a full review of this series, I'll judge it. I mean, it was pretty decent and the intros and endings were okay as well.


Character: 9/10


I liked how the characters actually kind of develop in this series. I personally really find it pleasant that we got to look at Ciel's past, and how Sebastian became his Butler. I also find it funny that Lady Elizabeth is Ciel's Fiancée. I mean, she's so positive and cheery, while he's really dark and evil. What a great combination! xP  


Enjoyment:10/10!


Overall:9/10 <3


I would really recommend this anime to people who like demons and a horror-ish (not really) type of anime. Now, what are you waiting for?! Sebastian is one hell of a butler after all.

STORY: The anime takes place during the Victorian-era in England. The plot primarily focuses on the relationship between Ciel Phantomhive and his butler Sebastian. Even though it is episodic, there are some in-depth storylines that the anime does get into (especially when it involves the past of the Phantomhive family). There is a lot of action, history, mystery and comedy!
CHARACTERS:
Ciel Phantomhive: He's very mature for a 13-year old! He has a cold soul and always serious and out for vengeance! Ciel is the owner of his family's company and is being taken care of by his butler/guardian. He is still a child a heart becauseCiel loves to play games (primarily chess). Ciel is also seen wearing an eyepatch during the anime.\n
Sebastian: He is a hell of a butler. Sebastian's loyalty does without question. He is very devoted to protect Ciel and will do anything under his command. Sebastian can also be seen as a mysterious figure... Since this man can do it all... who is he really? What is his main intentions?\n\n
OVERALL:\n
I've watched this anime DUBBED in English and the voice overs are pretty good. Personally, the characters play a big part behind the anime's success. It is great to see the storylines and pasts of Ciel and his family (along with some of the other characters too). Plus, the mystery and cliffhangers in the episodes contain the suspense that makes you want to watch more. Luckily, there are some comedic relief to balance the serious elements out. Even though there are a few flaws in the anime, I definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys the mysteries of crime and history, and the comedic relief that lets us continue to laugh and enjoy the fun.

This anime is kinda fucked up, which is one of the many reasons I love it.
The story itself can be a little confusing, but it's very good and really heartbreaking. The characters are very interesting. Some of the characters turn out to be something you did not expect which really changes your view and just shows you never really can be sure of who a person is. 
So at times this anime can be really confusing and fucked up, which sounds bad but really adds to it all. It makes it really interesting and it just made me love it even more. 
About the animationof this, I liked how it's a pretty dramatic anime, but with the animations they managed to make it very funny at times too.\n
Would definitely recommend.

Kuroshitsuji is either a hit or miss anime for certain viewers. Most either find the show to be extremely enjoyable or pretentious and bad. But for me I thoroughly enjoyed the series.
Story: 8
I gave the story category  a rating of 8 because of how things piece in together. I did not give a 9 or 10 just because of the first few episodes. I even went back to watch the first few episodes after I had finished the show. The first few episodes are sort of choppy and vague and don't give much of a sense of meaning because of how vauge the plotis portrayed during these episodes. Later on the story pieces together very nicely but I suggest if you want to watch this series, don't solely base it off of the confusion of the first episodes.


Art: 8

I gave the art category a rating of 8 because of how the animation is presented. To be frank, Kuroshitsuji has one of my favorite art styles i've seen in anime. The character design is usually very sleek and gives a certain flair to each character, making them their own. But he reason I didn't give a score of 9 or 10 was because of certain art in scenes that didn't flow as well as I would've personally liked. As well as the color not being as crisp. But I gave it an overall 8 because the art is presented in a unique way (reason why the action scenes are my favorite because of the crisp art style and attention to detailing).


Sound: 8

I gave the sound category a rating of 8 because of how the sound appeals to the viewer. The soundtrack is quite stunning (all of the openings in the Kuroshitsuji series get even better as the go along) and has such a significant feel to all of the music pieces. But the vocals really depend. Depending on whether you listen to the sub or dub is your choice. I can't give a too high rating or too low of a rating just because of the sound because it depends on the choice by the viewer. But if you pick either dub or sub, the music is still very good.


Character: 9

I gave the character category a rating of 9 because of how the characters are portrayed during the anime. First, let's talk about character design. The outward appearance for each character is unique and gives every character a sense of personality and purpose. It's not like looking at each character and seeing someone who isn't memorable. Nearly every character is memorable from appearance alone. And on to the character development. Every main character has a significant personality and story that is always seen as interesting. Whether the character is mysterious or has tons of flaws, each character is interesting in their own way. Some background characters may not be a favorite but a few main ones with their own individual personalities and way of thinking brings a real spark to the show. A good kind of show can give you characters you may come to hate. But an even better show can bring you characters you love to hate with the power of bringing such a significant personality to a character.


Enjoyment: 9

I gave the enjoyment category a rating of 9 because of how the show appealed to me. I had a great time watching this show because of how everything was paced and spread out into a very dramatic and interesting show to watch. I enjoyed the characters and the plot and how everything had become established. It kept my attention 90% of the time.


Overall: 8

I gave the overall category a rating of 8 because of how the show was presented. Obviously I couldn't give the show a 9 or 10 because, even a good show has a few flaws and bumps in the road. But to be fair, it was extremely entertaining and has been one of my favorite shows i've seen. I've even re watched it more than once as well. It had a solid impact on me and really made me want to see more. If you watch it and enjoy it, I suggest finishing out the rest of the series as well. I highly suggest watching this anime, I don't think you'll regret it.

First ever anime I ever watched. Still love it and rewatched it a few times. Makes me want a demon butler (honestly I've actually tried) and got me into the deep, dark black hole which is anime.
I love it because it's witty but dark with a gripping story line. Unfortunately there are a couple of cultural mistakes but it's not overly distracting. For instance they reference hot springs in England. The las volcanic activity we had was an exceptionally rare tremor that was miles away in the ocean and all it caused was a few wheelie bins to fall over.
I can relate to bothmain characters and Grell. Sebastian is what I act like, Ciel is my spirit animal as he acts exactly how I feel and Grell is me when I've had too much sugar or coffee, (apart from the fact I'm asexual)\n\n
Rated 9/10

The setting is alright, it's in the Victorian Era and stuff, story's a little predictable, with Sebastian a little too overpowered, and it's full of yaoi themes that pretty much take away the enjoyment of the show.
This anime can be thrilling at times, but other times it would be annoying, because of all the yaoi fanservice that seems to cater to girls or people interested in yaoi themes. If you're into that stuff, then this anime is for you, but for me, I wouldn't recommend it.
For the character designs, Ciel has the shota-ish kind of ook, and the way he's dressed is provocative for allthe yaoi/shotacon fans, and it sorta takes away the essence of the plot sometimes. \n\n
As for the music, I don't remember any piece that left a good impression in me, so yeah.

Hello.
First of all, I have to say that Kuroshitsuji is one of my favourite animes. 
What doesn`t mean I will play all nice, but I had, in fact, a good time seeing it.
Story (7)
The concept of this anime is amazing, the ideia by itself is a 10 stars coin. Victorian age, that is a rich time scenary, combined with a boy that had made a contrac with a demon. Well, in fact, this sounds cool because it is cool.
The big problem is that Kuroshitsuji is a bit "an everything" anime and the bordelines between the different styles are very, very sharpen up accentuating things thatend up being pretty odd (P!ATD reference XD... ok, sorry). 

The comedy spoils the serious momments, but it`s welcome sometimes. They just overdue a bit. 

And... I feel like I`m going to be hated for this... I didn`t like the Yaoi tones in this anime AT ALL.

Here they came... the sticks and stones!

Well, let me explain. I`m not a fan of Yaoi, but I find it entertaining in some concepts, you see? But NOT in this anime, not the way it was used. There were many excuses for fans to shipp Sebastian with Ciel and... it shouldn`t be that way, Ciel is a little boy and Sebastian a demon that can`t feel love. But in some scenes I really could see the "underline" message of this possible pairing. It was a bit like Arashi no Yoru ni. The 2 characters are friends but we can imagine them other way with ease (but I did like it in that film, here I didn`t) 

It can be o.k and even really good for some, but I, personally, would had prefered that the fanservice would go down quite a bit and the potencial darkness of the anime would be above over the other genres, not comedy above it nor fanservice above it.

The plot was a bit messy sometimes, maybe because they didn`t follow the manga exactly.

But it IS a wonderful anime, with a very decent plot. We have many things, ladies and gentleman, in this anime, we have mistery, we have history, we have action and supernatural. And of course lots of fanservice that, even when it don`t make sense, can be entertaining.

P.s: They could also had explored that Victorian age a bit more. They did, but I wanted deeper. 


Art (10) 

It`s so beautiful, the backgrounds, the characters design, that awesome clothes... 

I didn`t see much anime, so forgive me if I´m wrong, but I do think it was perfectly well designed this anime. 


Sound (9,5) 

The opening and respective animation catched my attention immediatly. Cool music for an opening, I don`t use to like openings, what a surprise. 

But then I heard "I`m alive" and I was like "Meh" it`s a bit strange for an ending song on an anime like this but I got used to and it switted the comedy momments (but you must admit that when one of the anime episodes ends on a dark vibe sounds funny hearing "I`m alive" following). At least the chibis are so cute that I never skipped the ending. 

And then came Lacrimosa, that perfect piece of music art that I have on my ipod to replay again and again, it`s so touching and it totally gave us goosebumps and we realize that the end of Ciel was close (or I though it was cause... [Angered spoiler]... season 2... that season 2 spoiled one of the best finals in anime world. It was the type of final that leaves our heart ankored with the feeling of sadness for Ciel but fulfilness that it in fact ended dark[End of spoiler]

Anyway... about the soundtrack... is very unique... and in a good way.

And the character`s voice was good, good voice actors were used in this anime. 


Characters (8) 


I don`t know what to say about Ciel. The bratty personality of his is better than a sweet-hearted one, the cinrcunstances made him bitter, is compreensible.

Is that kind of character that we sometimes like his attitudes and sometimes we just want to choke him. But that`s good, it`s like a person, right? We hate even if we love.

And now Sebastian... 

hum... 

He is my favourite character... in all the animes that I saw.

There are people who hate him because he is to perfect but I he is perfect just in actions and such... his personality is completaly f***** up. He is evil, not prince charming /although the anime keeps it hide because it is not good for fangirls/

I would like him even if the demonic side of Sebastian would had been more explored (my mashoquist said hello here) but anyway. Sebastian is a cool character.

I also really liked: Madam Red, Undertaker, Fred Abberline

O.k: The others 

I don`t like: Lizzie (on the anime she is particulary annoying), Grell (he is useless, it`s on the show just for the fanservice), Pluto (again, is useless and not so well explained) 


Enjoyment (8) 

Not much to say here. 

I already said it all!


Total score: 8,5 

(9, but it`s a low 9)

This isn't an anime I expected to like. The title itself reeks of Hot Topic and bug-eyed fangirls. But I love it, and you MIGHT too. 
I'll start right off the bat with something a bunch of people dislike about "Black Butler": its inconsistent tone. In an instant, it will flit from dark, Latin-singing choirs and ominous dialogue to levity normally reserved for zany comedies. For me, the juxtaposition works, and it's a large part of what makes "Black Butler" so palatable. I find a world is more fleshed out and relatable if it doesn't take itself too seriously. Yes, Sebastian is a demon whoultimately wants to feast on Ciel's soul - but that's just how demons roll. It's FAR more engrossing to focus on the nuances of Sebastian and Ciel's simultaneous relationships as lord/master and prey/hunter, and how both relationships affect one another. Because the show chooses not to constantly dramatize the "demonic" elements, it can instead devote its attention to crafting a multi-dimensional world, characters, and relationships. We could spend hours on Ciel ruminating over his decision, but isn't it more fun to... not? We know that if he backed out (which he wouldn't, because he's fucking Ciel), the show would be over. It would be silly and boring to watch him debate his decision over and over set to dramatic music when we could be having fun solving mysteries and exploring the VERY unique world the show lets us sink our teeth into. Wouldn't you agree?\n\n
I have yet to read the manga, so I can't comment on when and where the anime deviates. I enjoyed the ending the anime gave us, but I look forward to seeing the ending the manga chooses. I love that this show has boosted A-1 Pictures financially so much, because "Book of Circus" is FAB as is "Book of Murder." And they're coming out with "Book of the Atlantic" in 2017 as well! Huzzah!

Story-9
I gave this a 9 although I would give it a 9.5 if I could. I love the darkness of the genre, but I also enjoyed the intense action and mystery too.  The plot is a very unique one that follows the main character, Ciel, in his quest for vengeance. Of course, there are also arcs involving his job, which is solving mysteries for the queen. I really enjoyed both the arc plots and the main plot and the way that they wove in with each other. The only reason I gave story a 9 was because sometimes it was really hard to waitthrough an arc when I really just wanted the main plotline to keep on moving.


Art- 10


The artistic aesthetics of this anime are very dark- which totally fits the genre.  The characters are designed well, and I really thought the artwork was beautiful while at the same time not over or underdone.


Sound- 8


As far as the opening goes, I usually skip it (not because I don't like it, I just want to get to the episodes.) It's not particularly remarkable in my opinion, but it's certainly not bad.  The background music and sound effects are very well done, but once again, I don't think there was anything super fantastic about them other than that they perfectly fit the dark atmosphere of the anime.


Character- 10


The characters are probably the number one thing about this anime.  Their personalities and their relationships are all very intriguing, but I was especially drawn in by the relationship between Sebastian and Ciel. It's very complex and very well done. There are times when the watcher simultaneously loves and hates the characters all at once and it's addictive. Not to mention the less focal characters, like a certain grim reaper with obsessive fantasies that provides great comedy, the household servants with hilarious problems and shadowy pasts, and the annoying yet somehow endearing fiance- they all captivate you and grab your attention.


Enjoyment- 10


I must say I loved this anime, it's probably one of my favorites of all time.  It has plenty of action elements, but I also really enjoyed the mystery and subtleties it has.  


Overall- 10


A fabulous anime. If you like a darker genre with a lot of thrill, this is for you!

Usually an anime that wants to become everything usually would result to self-destruction such as “Kyou kara Maou!” and “Ichiban Ushiro no Daimaou;” you will find yourself lost whether you are in Yaoi land, magic school or  the battle field. 
Kuroshitsuji had successfully infiltrated those odds and developed into something ingenious. 
”Victorian, British, musical, folklore…
Comedy, drama, yaoi, relationships…
Demons, death, blood, violence…
Shonen, battles, supernatural, mystery, heroes and villains…”
Story (8/10)
There is a saying, “expect the unexpected.” This sums up everything about the story. The different genres were utterly blended together in perfect harmony. Unlike others who would leave the dish half-cooked, Kuroshitsuji will serve it preciselyas a perfect butler would. Although the story has a striking resemblance to Hellsing, they gave it their own finishing touches that actually have a different sensation.


Art (6/10)


The Art is admirable but not quite distinctive from other anime but the way they created the characters definitely indubitably accommodated the era and the personalities of each characters. The eye marking is undeniably unoriginal and the pentagram on Sebastian’s hand greatly resembles the ones in Hellsing but other than that, it is quite a catch, especially the butler whose face you cannot forget. 


Sound (10/10) 


The music is discernibly pure perfection as your heart starts throbbing to the melody and quivers throughout your entire body. The sweet melodies are perfectly in sync with the Victorian era while the thrilling battle music gives your heart a double pounding. 


Character (10/10)


The varieties and distinctiveness of the characters and the driving force it causes to the entire story itself. The hell of a phrase in this anime not only suits the character perfectly but it is also quite contagious and you would find yourself transforming into his very form. They also successfully pulled a barrier between the serious main characters from the rest who are quite the opposite. Although they are quite the serious type, they would find a way through your subconscious and make you laugh. The balance between serious and funny, childish and mature, good and evil are perfectly rolled up into this intriguing anime. 


*Overall, the anime is unique in a way at the same time unoriginal…quite the irony. The final moments is quite the shocker but at the same time you would feel something missing but in the end, it has one of the most beautiful endings in any anime that I have seen. 


I recommend you to see Kuroshitsuji II. If you find this a dull or boring, the next season is a hundred times better because of the added psychological feel and seriousness.

The different supernatural creatures being butlers (Shinigami, Angels, Puppets and Demons) was entertaining.
The only reason it missed out on a 10/10 was the fact that you really didn't learn anything about Ciel's parents (the reason why he was getting revenge) until the very end.  You hear a little bit about them from Madam Redat the start but that is about it until the last few episodes.
